reviewText:
With a couple of hundred more hours played then it shows, I also played pre Steam release for a short amount of time.

The Positives:

Mortal Online has alot of things hardcore players will love to have. Its steep learning curve. unforgiving pvp, Those nerves that tingle when your most precious items and your guilds assets are on the line.

It has an amazing crafting system that I have yet to see in any other MMO.  The combat system takes some time to get used to it but feels rather clunky at first. Mounted combat was really fun to me.

The taming and breeding systems are pretty decent.

The Negatives:

Some of the systems in the game are broken and incomplete for a title that has been out for 5 years. For example spear stance, the backstab mechanic, the akward hitboxes for certain melee weapons, the ranged combat with bows is very erratic. There are virtually no combat encounters that do not involve hit and run. Unless you include Seige mechanics, that involves players destroying your assets when your peak players are offline. No different then Ark Survival.

The UI is very simplistic for a game that has been out for so long. So many Inventory bugs happen daily that  doing /droploot to check your gear for invisible items is a thing. Many lores for creatures that are not even in the game are still cluttered in the players skill list, making it even more diffcult for players who already have a hard time learning the game.

The community is so secretive about everything that its hard for new players to even thrive. You can barely even get someone in your guild to tell you the correct recipe for weapons and armor to make them worthwhile. Sadly it is because most of the players in the community are on a huge powertrip. They are afraid to be on an equal level of playing as newcomers. It is also why you find very few guides about the game. The official reddit for MO has less then one thousand registered people. I am sure this pushes players away from the game.

if you ever really want to know how full of themselves these kids are just take a walk over to the offical mortal online forums in the media section and watch the videos and the trash talking that these guys do on a daily basis. Soon after check the guild politics section and just read the constant pe nis wagging that happens.

The last thing I am going to say about this game is the community is downright TOXIC, There are a few players that exist to try and make the game a better place. But overall the game is filled with either present or past hacks / hackers. Undercover gold and asset selling for real cash money.  GM's that abuse power by not hearing out two sides to story or warning you about things before punishing you. Veterans who think that you have to respect them because they have mastered the combat system and therefore will even grief thier own guildmates. (Msg me if you want twitch recordings) and the WORST OF ALL.

A community of players that will use DDOS programs constantly on each others Communications during times of war. Or just for any kind of revenge they deem necessary. Abuse of TS adresses. IP adresses, to anyone in thier own guilds and to other guilds.

Alot of the functions of the game are client side and can be exploited very easily. Its why duping of items has and more then likely is still is a problem that is reoccuring and hard to track and ban people for.

I think thats about enough. I just unsubscribed and will take another year long break from the game and check once again if they have fixed any of these issues or the community has changed.

Sad thing is I dont really hold up my hopes. =(

As a side note, the pet pathing is the absolute worst I have ever seen. Three to four tickets to a GM a day just to have them returned to you after they dissapear through the world.

Edited for grammar, because I am a scrub.

reviewText:
Enter noob wearing some leather as a robe and leggings, with a helmet which may or may not be metal and equipped with the METAL SHORTSWORD OF UNMANLYNESS and WORN SHEILD OF LIFE.

I was so overloaded with dead animals that my run speed was comparable to a fast ant. I needed to get to a vendor, who's entrance was over a hill, far along the wall to the city I had to circumvent. I was going to be rich.

Yet at the same time, I knew it would look suspicious to be seen moving at such a slow speed while running. Enter my adorable deer like pet I called NotaBear who I would stop and turn to whenever another person was in sight.

As I neared the arena I had to pass before closing in on the city gates, I knew encounters would become more frequent. By this time my daughter was cheering me on!

I made it past the arena, only stopping to socialize with NotaBear 3 times, the end was in sight! And then it happened.

Enter a man in silver robes covering his body. Blinding me and filling me with fear, he asked what I was doing. How much gold I had. What I was carrying. He told me the command to type that would drop all the loot in my bags, and he would let me live if I dumped my gear.

I told him I only had meat. He told me to dump my gear. My daughter told me to dump my gear. I continue to back up with my shield out, hoping to stall for 20 minutes as I walk backwards to the city. You have no idea how slow going this is...

I am losing all hope. He is telling me he going to kill me. The end is near.

Behind him I see a man on a horse with the largest bow I have seen in the game. I yell out that I am being robbed. He stops. My robber turns and greets the man by name with humility and fear!!

My Savior asks what is transpiring, and I repeat that he is trying to steal all my meat. My Savior retorts with a funny meat joke and we all laugh.

However my robber still attempts to get me to drop my gear. My crawling backpeddle to the gates looks more hopeful, as my Savior tells me to continue into the city and that this man will leave me alone. I offer my thanks.

And then the robbers horse attacks me! Shield up I quickly learn to parry this magnificent creatures attacks. Life is dropping, at 60% life my Savior notices what is happening and runs to the rescue.

The robber runs. The horse runs. The Savior gives chase. Moments later, my robber lays dead, and I am free to head into the city, proudly displaying the wounds I earned to keep my treasure!

Best 43 silver I ever made.

reviewText:
Been playing this game for 3 weeks and still cant successfully do anything without being murdered by reds at city gates, theives taking everything i own, blue blocking players, and being killed at vendors my criminals.
This game is filled with nothing but griefers that will pray on new players making sure they wont leave their starting cities by killing them and taking their stuff. I had to keep on starting from scratch and back up to where I was just to be killed by a vet on horses who armor are almost indestructible and whose weapons can cut right through your armor and kill you with one blow. Even 2 AI guards has a hard time killing them and the guards are powerful. Thats how strong these players are. They even camp the graveyards in the cities where noobs go to make money.

Also other players will keep on killing your horse/donkey, the ones you bought with your gold that takes you a couple of days to make, just for the heck of it anywhere even infront of guards just to watch you rant. Most vets in this game are murderers which are worst than criminals. They prey on noobs and gets a kick out of killing them while they're trying to learn the game. They do this because they know they have years and years exp in this game before it came out on steam. You will barely get to explore the world alive because they are also patrolling the lands outside the city to track and kill you. The only way to explore the lands is as a ghost. Be warn, when you revive at a priest, there will be a vet with their name in bold red letters which signals they are murders and they will kill you. Do not download this game because this game is made to support griefers. Im ending my subscription and hanging this game up. I was so excited to see a game like this but once you exp it, you will be let down. Nothing but bad community and too many criminal RP. Today was my last day. What did it was, I bought a horse which cost 4 gold and 50 silver. Went to go buy equipment for it. Had a large bag equiped on my horse so I can carry items to trade. Bought a 1000 food for the horse which cost 1 gold for the journey. I put on my armor and equiped myself with my shield and weapon. got on the horse and was ready to explore. Soon as I stepped out the city gates i made it 100 yards away from the gate. All the sudden POW get hit by a powerful mace and my guy feel off the horse and died. Then I watched my horse fall from one blow.

A screen popped up with the murderer name saying report murderer. For what? He is already red and enjoys killing! So far I died more than 30 times in within 16.6 hrs from blue blockers, murderers, and criminals. I lost 4 donkeys and 2 horses from criminals. 10 of those deaths was me trying to leave the city and 2 of those 10 deaths was from me reviving at a priest in a town i traveled to as a ghost just to die from a murderer patrolling the town buildings. For those that dont know what blueblockers are, they are players jumping infront of you while you are swinging your weapon to kill a animal or the dead just for you to accidentally hit them so you can turn grey which grants everybody to kill you and take all your stuff because your now a criminal. Until this game is fixed and im done. Good luck to anybody who decides to download this game.

reviewText:
I've played Mortal Online a bit before it came to Steam and this game has a wealth of good ideas. Alas, there are far too many problems with the game, the hardware backing the game, the devs, and the community for any of those good ideas to shine through.

Here are a few of those good ideas and why they don't work.

+Mortal is now on Steam  with all the benefits that come with it. For the game and the playerbase, I think this is sorely needed, but I'll get back to that.

-Unfortunately, the servers simply cannot handle the influx of new players. Multiple tries are required to log in and gameplay in general is laggy and unresponsive compared to how the game used to run. Especially with Mortal's dynamic combat system, this can make the game almost unplayable.

+The character customization is very unique. Your character is generated by choosing your heritage. The not often seen feature of having your age and height affect your stats is an interesting addition as well.

-However, the distribution of stats can be rather confusing, as there are no tooltips that tell you exactly how each stat point affects your character, forcing you to just guess which stats will match your playstyle.

+The game has open survival-esque PvP in all areas, only limited to how long you think you can last without getting killed yourself.

-This is poorly implemented, however. You will find yourself accidentally taking swings at players, especially in the densely populated starting zones, labeling you a criminal and being killed shortly after. The combat itself is very clunky and slow compared to the speed people can move. Most PvP battles consist of bouncing at your opponent, hoping your attack will connect first or being assaulted from behind while your attacker flees.

+The game has a rewarding loot and crafting system  and you can even loot the items of dead players.

-The latter being inappropriate for this type of game. Mortal is supposed to play like an RPG, not a survival game. You can spend hours amassing materials and crafting items as a simple craftsman with no intent of combat, only to be slain and lose all of your items rather unceremoniously.

+The economy is entirely player run. Most items are made for players, by players. This game may be the only MMORPG I've seen that actually has honest to goodness crafting guilds that function like a real business.

-The economy is broken as hell. Unlike games that have a player run economy that is gently shifted by the judgment of the developers for maximum fun, this one was just left to its own devices. Low level gear is oversaturated and difficult to sell, making the early game merchant completely implausible without first having a high level beefstick to harvest better materials.
Just as well, high level market is cornered to the point of it being cheaper simply to spend the time and effort to make it yourself. Since there is such a high risk of losing all of your items upon death, it makes you question why you'd want to put in the effort at all.

Now that I've covered most of the 'good' aspects of the game, here are some of the purely negative ones.

-The playerbase is horrible. As I hinted at before, I'm hoping Steam will make this game's community a bit more bearable. Almost all high level characters will kill lower levels to grief them. Most are unhelpful and others are downright caustic. Of course that doesn't go for every player, but the sheer number of simply mean spirited people are scarily high.

-The developers don't care about the game at all. I must admit that it has improved a small amount since the last time I played. Unfortunately the game still seems to be in a constant state of neglect. Bugs and issues are everywhere and some are still present since I last played in 2011.

-Most of the GMs are unhelpful. Again, this doesn't go for every mod, but there have been recorded cases of GMs repeatedly scamming players for real world money. On a smaller scale, GMs will constantly 'play' with their privileges in ways that actively disrupt the game, such as spawning bosses in low level areas or even verbally attacking specific players in global chats.

-The game has some very seedy business practices. Not limited to: Capping player skills at a ridiculously low value unless they have a subscription, asking for weirdly personal information such as your address and full name unless you are a subscriber, and lifting any ban if you donate.

-If you are a subscriber, you are allowed to take items from other player's inventories. Plain and simple. You just... take stuff. Like... What the hell, right?

That about wraps up what's wrong with this game. In this state, I absolutely cannot recommend it. The game has some great potential and fun gameplay, but a hardcore reorganization is in order before this game becomes anything that's worth your time.

+++You can also see some top notch elf ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Mortal online should be called Potential: The Game.  It is a game full of unlimited potential, from its elder scrolls-esque combat system to its open world.  Unfortunately, after years of playing, I found myself constantly waiting for it to meet that potential.  From constant bugs, terrible combat balancing, to staff corruption, it is one thing after another with this train-wreck of a game.

First things first, the CEO, Henrik Nystrom has no clue what goes on in his own game.  Having dealt with the guy in regards to the testing of new mechanics and game bugs, he is clueless.  There are mechanics in the game from years ago that do not work and he still has no idea whether or not they do, requiring him to hear such feedback from the playerbase and sometimes getting quite indignant when faced with the problems of his game resorting to calling those who bring them up trolls even if the feedback is provided in a respectful manner.  When assisting on the test team, he would blatantly ignore feedback regarding bugs, pvp mechanics, etc and simply to whatever he liked.  He does give the appearance of interacting with the community, though this isn't hard when they remove any type of criticism from the public view.

He is also blind to the corruption of the game, allowing players (of low moral character) to perform GM duties for his game.  One of the previous counselors is actually well known for monetarily scamming money from other players multiple times via various schemes.  This player-based GM system ends up being a major issue in a full-loot game where assets and the element of surprise actually matter.  GMs scout locations for other players, spawn demons and other monsters on top of other players in an attempt to soften them up for their personal friends and major game decisions in terms of cheating, hacking, etc are made by players who have and hold obvious bias.  This is greatly apparent after the donation system where some of the largest backers have experienced some of the greatest success by having relics (items that provide guild specific buffs) dropped in their backyard the day after losing them to other guilds.  I've also seen players with high donations who were banned from their forums for breaking the rules immediately unbanned afterward.  It is pretty safe to say this occurs in game as well.

But that aside, let us get to the game.  The game's graphics look like something from 2010.  Textures are recycled unreal engine 3 type fluff.  It was excusable for a time, but not for a game attempting to make it big on steam.  I'd give them a six out of ten as the game can look beautiful at times, lighting-wise, but any close look is a mess.  It isn't unheard of to get stuck in the mesh as the whole thing is a mess and you can get stuck on something in the middle of a fight and end up losing the equipment you worked hard to get.  Thankfully, they did some work a year or so ago and this improved it in some areas, but made it worst in others.  UI is your typical fare and is reminiscent of an elder scrolls game/clone.

I won't even go into mechanics deeply as it is a very touchy subject.  The game favors large numbers and zergs as they call it.  There was a long period when skill mattered and it was possible to consistently go against the odds, but those days are gone after large donators constantly complained as well as week old players.  If you play now, then combat is simple enough with directional swings and blocks, but you're best finding a guild with a decent amount of players as you'll just end up getting zerged.  If you have grand aspirations as a new group, be prepared to merge or ally into another as that seems to be the norm for newer players.  Once again, this is a full-loot pvp game.

Murder system is iffy.  Five kills and you turn red which means you can't go into a town.  Some feel that is harsh, some feel it isn't harsh enough.  You burn murder counts every 8 hours.  Get under 5 and you're back to blue.  Taken from another review to give you a newer player's idea of the game, A thief can steal from you and if you attack him he is able to kill you without getting a murder score.  There are some people on this game with over 1000 murders that have been free from murder score and they walk around in the cities all day.  This is hardly justice at all and any new player will see this as a troll game and quit once educated to this process."  Take from that what you will.

The community...Well this game features one of the most toxic and destructive communities that I've ever seen.  It is very small and includes those who would lie

reviewText:
Mortal Online - More than a first look.

If you have the majority of reviews of this game, most are written by either users who:

1. Played for 10 minutes.
2. Played for maybe a week.
3. Complain because others are better at the game.
4. Don't understand all games have bugs (Yes this one has quite a few, however this game is so good it doesn't matter since they are not game breaking, just irritating.)
5. (Probably the worst... ) Can't handle the player community of this game.. Yes, it's probably the worst community, not going to try and ignore this.  It's a Full loot PVP hardcore sandbox... its going to bring out the worst.

Me, I've played for several years, before mortal came to steam. With steam its getting alot better, and at a much faster rate. But it's brings COD fans, idiots, and immature user's who do not understand, or even like these sort of hardcore games.  I've dealt with countless bugs, the horrific community, and sadly, terrible customer support.
But none of this, would ever weigh heavily enough to stop me from playing this game.

I've always wanted a game like this, and this is exactly it. No other game offers what mortal online does.

The combat:

Melee: You have directional attacks, directional blocking, different damage types (Blunt, peircing, slashing) And armor/resisting the same (Blunt, peircing, slashing). So not only do you have a variety of how you attack, you have a variety of damage types. Once you learn the game enough you can look at another player and seeing their armor type, and materials it's made of, knowing what its weak/strong against. The combat in this game is the MOST fun I've experienced.  And the absolute best part, It's not super gear reliant. Myself and many others have defeated players with higher end gear, while being naked with a started sword known as worn shortsword". So your not 100% screwed if they out gear you. This combat system is skill and knowledge based

not gear reliance based.

What is there to do in mortal? Plenty.

You can be a crafter

reviewText:
I pushed a guy off a ledge with a shield and he came back up and flipped me off.

REAL REVIEW:

Another reason to not believe Steam reviews. This game is unlike other MMOs in that it DOES NOT HOLD YOUR HAND AT ALL. You wanna learn how to craft armor and weaponry? Well, go do it then! You don't know how? Well find the trainers! You don't know where the trainers are because the game doesn't have a map? Well look around then!

People are getting massively butthurt because the game is not supposed to be easy and simplified for idiots. It's meant as a spiritual successor to Ultima Online, and so far it is in the sandbox elements at least. The game almost entirely lacks quests, too, and that is also ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ people off.

It's a sandbox MMO. I thought people like sandbox games? Oh wait, they do if they're simplified to the point that children can pick them up and play them like a master. This is not that kind of game.

reviewText:
Mortal online can be a great game if you sarround yourself with the right ppl.
This game is a true sandbox mmo which is very hard to comeby now a days with a skill system similar to the elderscrolls series.
I personally have had a blast with my guild through the highs and lows that this game can bring.

To adress some of the negative comments i have been reading here are some tips to get the most out of mortal.

1. Get out of the starting cities Morin khur and tindrem as fast as possible. This is where you will find the most thieves and the most griefers who come there to take advantage of your inexperience. Avoid toxai as well since there is a well known guild that gets off at killing newbies there.

2. You are going to die and lose stuff at some point. This can be frustrating but it is a pvp full loot game so become smart about banking stuff you dont need to carry around.

3. This game is meant to be played with a guild. You will have a really hard time without guidance and help from vets in the guilds. This isnt like any other mmo where you can just look up a guide from newbie to vet and be fine. A good place to look for guilds is the mortal online forums guild recruitment section where guilds  display their playstyle and tell you a little bit about themselves. Join a helpful guild as soon as possible but do your homework on what kind of an outfit you are getting yourselves into.

Most of all have fun with the group you play with. In any game its the quality people that i laugh in teamspeak with that keep me coming back.
Good luck ingame

reviewText:
I've probably played a total of 2500-5000 hours, the majority of them pre-steam.

So much unused potential.

One only has to go as far as check the reviews and steamcharts of this game to see the sucess of the steam release.

http://steamcharts.com/app/287920

For the past one to two years they've been progressing backwards in development effectively removing features from the game.

The game lacks sufficient funding and competent developers in order for the game to be developed at an acceptable phase. A certain stubborn CEO made sure the steam release wouldn't succeed.

There's so many placeholders in the game of content that hasn't been released yet being added into the game over three years ago.

A proper magic system,Tailoring,Fletching,Sarduccan papyrus,pottery and the list goes on.

A toxic and stubborn community. Granted the game was released back in 2010 and a big portion of the people that still play the game have been since release.

Anything negative posted about the game on the forums will end in a swift locked thread and anything too critical will be terminated. The Mortal Online Forums has a no tolerance policy for negative criticism. The Forums are regulated in a similar fashion of an oppressive regime.

Are you willing to play a game which is basically in a pre-alpha stage with various bugs such as items in your inventory becoming invisible same for your bank, pets getting stuck,enemies being invulnerable to damage and mind you all of these issues exist in a full loot pvp game. And getting help usually takes a very long time.Aswell as having to deal with a support team that's terrible.

Overall the game suffers from lack of funding,incompetent develeopment,support team and the CEO has personally interfered with the game disregarding what's best for the game in order to fulfill his ''vision''.

Also.. The game's lore is supposedly written in 'Advanced Swedish' a language unknown to myself and being a swede myself that's rather odd. Appearently they haven't been able to find a person to translate it for the past 5 years.

The game lost roughly 81% of the steam population during the first 4 months of it being released.
The population of the game is not large enough to support the ingame economy that it is designed to have forcing everyone to be self sufficient, subscribe 1-2 accounts and have 4 character slots each and you have to pay.



This Game is        poop

reviewText:
I will keep it short and real. This is an 8/10 game. If you liked Ultima Online before trammel, if you like Eve Online,  and if you like and could handle darktide Ac, then you will love this game.

It is an old school mmo, which I have missed so much. Actions have consequences, death hurts, player politics impacts the world and you! You can be more or less anything you want, BUT you cannot be everything you want. You must choose what paths to follow. You want to be a great swordsmen? You can do that, you want to be a master smith? Sure thing, but you wont be both on the same character.

The game offers tons of freedom, and with such there will be childish griefers that camp the noob spawns and pick the pockets of the unaware in main cities etc, but the freedom to do so is what makes this great. You can be a total tool, OR you can walk a more noble path and help defend the innocent from the griefers of the land. Join a guild or form one, build a house, or a tower, or a town. Change the face of Nave!... yes you can do this if you work at it.

I have now been playing for several weeks and as a mmo vet of most that have been released, I find this game so refreshing.

Why then is it not a 10?..... Bugs. The game is still not 100%. There are mesh holes across the map. Getting stuck or losing a pet into such is not uncommon, though the gms are quick and helpful in fixing this. Pathing issuse occur, some of the features are not fully enabled ( like dynamic weather).   There is also a painful lack of knowledge available where I feel it should be readily available. Guild interactions, wars, Housing placement etc are all far more difficult than they should be.

I also think the newb experience is very painful. Enough so that it likely scares off a lot more than it should. Players are given a short grace period of peace, but they often find themselves targets as soon as this runs out. They are given the impression that THIS is the game, and sadly quit before they can get out into the world and realize what a wealth of adventure awaits them.

These issues aside it is a fantastic game with enormous potential. If you are new, Stick with it!  Start in Tindrem as advised, it is a safer city.. and DO not let the morons that seek to scare you away suceed.
Learn what you can, bank often, and seek friends. There are many villains out there but there are also tons of very nice and helpful players.

Last thing. I was shocked and pleased to find out that there is a very decent role-play community out there. Good luck all and have fun!

(feel free to message me if you have questions or leave a reply/question and I will check back now and again)
Galiswyn Ta'Kier
Order of the Grifffin

reviewText:
Been playing this game for a while now (despite steam hours) and it's exactly everything I look for in an mmo.

Sandbox with full loot? Check.
Detailed crafting system that can encompass an entire character build? Check.
Skill based pvp/pve combat with many many varied builds? Check.
Player on Player looting and thieving? I'll kill you if you steal my gold.
Mounts? Pets? Taming giant 2 ton bears? exploding heads with your fists?

This is not a game for everyone, that's plain and simple. It is very hardcore, you WILL die MANY times to both the environment and other players. This is how you learn, this is how you flourish. Mortal Online is a game that will not hold your hand and coddle you. It is brutal and unforgiving, and this is why I play it, not many other games will give you an actual thrill for adventuring, or pure excitement when you finally battle down that mob the 2 shotted you. No game but Dark Souls (on launch week for the 360 when no one had any clue what was going on) gave me the same feels as this game.

Imagine Mount and Blade meets Ultima Online, hardcore sandbox MMo fans you have found your home.

Edit: Just to add, this game IS free to play, but I would say the f2p is more of a trial than anything else. Your skills will cap at 60 (albiet they will continue to level regardless so if you do go p2p you will level to those skills automatically to wherever you capped as f2p). The game is not p2w but there is a sub wall. I urge you to try it, and if it's your style you'll see why the people who play this are subbed. No other game, especially an MMo, gives you the freedom that Mortal Online gives you.

reviewText:
When I saw free to play that kind of deterred me but I'm really glad I tried it.

If you liked Ultima Online before the facet split - this might be for you. :)

-People can murder you at any time and take everything you have on you

-They can steal your things (from your inventory)

-They can make armor out of your skin


To a lot of people that might be frustrating and at times it can be but at other times it turns such occurances into epic tales of survival and triumph when you live through an attack despite overwhelming odds or recovering your belongings from your corpse before other people get their greedy mits on them.

Plus points:

-Very interesting crafting system with no (very few) fixed item recipes

-Taming, magic, archery, mount breeding, the works

-Incredible degree of freedom with according penalties (you can eat leather but dont complain if it gives you problems :P)

-Interesting weight system if you work out a lot like running or fighting or whatever and only eat ♥♥♥♥♥♥ food with low sustenance values you will waste away to a skinny twig (with penalties to your strength etc) - the opposite is also true if you only eat fatty food all the time and rarely move because you stay in town all the time crafting you will get fat ^^

-Be what you want to be, a thief, a feared murderer, trader, crafter, adventurer, tamer you name it

This game is not for you if you like:

-brainafk farming in the same spot without any awareness of your surroundings (you WILL die if you don't stay vigilant)

-keeping everything on your character or at least way more things than you are prepared to lose

-the idea that people can pickpocket you and steal stuff from your inventory

-questing sprees or any type of themepark-like game experience - you make your own adventure


If you give this a go never keep anything on you you're not prepared to lose - even in town.

A lot of the negative comments mention Blueblocking which is annoying but this mainly happens in the starting town and the graveyard but this once again comes down to situational awareness, always keep track of your surroundings if people lurk around you behaving suspiciously without actually doing something themselves they ARE probably out to get you in some way or another.
Keep enough distance from others so that if you swing your weapon they wont have enough time to run in front of your swing and generally don't swing your weapon around like a madman especially in the graveyard where lots of players are in a small space trying to get the spawning mobs.
Or leave town altogether and try to find your luck there where blueblocking is generally not an issue (but player killers are more prevalent so watch out)

Long story short I love this game so far it is strongly influenced by ultima online and the degree of freedom is fairly unparalleled. And while that of course opens the door to thieves and spawn killers and other things like that, it also enables you to have a very rewarding experience if you can weather the storm.
I enjoy the rush of knowing that training a skill outside of town or gathering things or whatever can turn into a fierce battle at any time - the risk is what makes things that happen in this game memorable, death has an impact.
Also beheading someone who killed you before and then making soup from their head or feeding it to your dog is incredibly satisfying :P

TLDR; Very rewarding experience if you don't let deaths and loss of items get to you. It is a hostile environment but that just increases the impact random acts of kindness have when a stranger passing by saves your life or hands you a suit of armor because you seem to have lost it all. (Dont beg for things it's unbecoming and everybody hates it ^^)

Strongly recommended but don't say I didn't warn you ;)

Cheers Wes

Just be careful, this game is potent.

reviewText:
One of the greatest, most unique and most bug filled mmos you'll ever play.

If you don't look at any guides you could get lost in one of the crafting systems for months and months. There's detail and depth everywhere no matter how you choose to live. Besides crafting(armor/weapon), gathering, hunting, butchering, alchemy, cooking, fishing, mining, woodcutting, extraction, refining.... There are also players that deal in politics, transportation, gambling, or trading guilds and vast empires. You will build up from nothing and possibly be beaten back down to poverty at times. It's a rule of life in Mortal, death can be around every corner and if you die, you will drop everything.

The most beautiful part is that it's almost entirely player driven. Any guide, map, or help you get will be from other players who were there first and put in the time to learn these crazy systems. The devs/GMs do very little except to give you some sand and a box. What you can do with it is awesome.

It is a niche game and not everyone will love it but if you enjoy this type of mmo then you'll see how amazing it truely is.

reviewText:
An unpolished and very unrefined game with alot of bugs and gamebreaking issues.
But also one of the games with alot of potential due to the large sandbox character and freedom presented to the people playing it.

Lets start with the positive things.

-The game has an large world with no instances where everyone plays together and can also block each other if he wants to.
- The game has an extensive and very free crafting system which allows crafters to actually distuingish themselves from others by improving their crafted and extracted materials by knowing techniques and recipes other dont know and wont find out.
- The game uses an realtime, first person combat system. You swing a sword block an enemys sword or take other actions like in an First Person Shooter game.
- Sandbox. You build, you craft, you gather and you steal whatever you can. No campaign and no level limits. If your an veteran of the game you can have yourself usable within 2 days.  Because aside from the skills learning which is very annoying sometimes. Everything else depends on you yourself.


Now for the Cons.

- The devs are very stubborn. Opinions from players are pretty much never listened to and they are not welcome either. So if your complaining too much you can be banned pretty fast and pretty long without even being told a reason.
- The game has alot of bugs. Yes really alot of bugs. From floating objects to falling through the ground or getting stuck in walls which will result in your death and loss of everything you carried with no chance to get it back because support does not reinburse losses from bugs or anything else.
- The game systems are very easy to circumvent which is not against the rules and thus allowing to kill others and plunder them within the city with the guards not taking any action as well as moving your mounts into safe positions where they cannot be attacked but still be loaded with stuff.  The game offers an list where the systems your not allowed to circumvent are listed. Anything not listed there is allowed.
- The community is very bad. As the game has been around for several years before it was released on steam. And has done a very poor job on bugfixing and improvements. The most people which stayed are the guys who are used to use these bugs and systems to their advantage. This also leads to them not liking the idea of more people joining the game which results in new players being killed everywhere and anywhere alot.
- Very very veeery slow patching and bugfixing. Importand patches only come around once or twice a year. And even hotifxes dont come faster than one or two months after an problem occured. Alot of bugs still accurate today have been there even in the closed beta.
- Not playable with older computers or slow internet connections. While you may still login and play. You will notice very fast that you will lag around alot. Monsters attack you despite being miles away from you. And things you want to gather will tell you they dont exist because your position in the world is different from where your client tells you you should be.
This can be so bad that your moved back over 1km because you hit an stone or wall somewhere on the server while you client just traveled all the way to another city.
- Freedom comes at an price. Castles and fortifications are build all around the world. Blocking content of the game or and looking very stupid where they are standing.
- Advertised as Free to Play title. This game is an free trial. And without Premium you are useless as crafter as well as an fighter or whatever because whatever you do will be worth next to nothing.
- Macros.... Better have some ready, they are legal in the game and the game design is laid out for their use. So if you do not use them you will be highly disadvantaged. (Pls make sure to check the list for prohibited macros first since some macros like automatic healing bots etc are NOT ALLOWED)

My advice. Get the Game for free. Take a good look for at least 2 weeks. And only after that decide wether its worth investing money or not. Because the game looks very good at start and in videos. But once you get into the actual game and start understanding whats going on around you. The illusions fades very fast and the game becomes very annoying.

reviewText:
Mortal Online is an incredible game, albiet very moody and covered in little bugs. I have never encountered a game with as much potential and freedom.

Spend hours living the life:
Of a simple gatherer, tending to your pet dog every now and again as he follows you around.
Of a politican, traveling town to town ushering people to join guilds, making friends, mending fences or breaking them.
Of a craftsmen, hammering down and creating your very own unique recipes for armor and weapons.
Of a warrior, slaying countless monsters, or people. Defend the weak, or destroy them.
Of a wildsmen, living the land and taming all sorts of wild creatures to accompany you, or to sell.
Of a mage, sending arcs of electricity and balls of flame into your enemies, or healing wounded allies.
Of a chef, a sparse profession, sweating as you struggle to find the perfect amount of salt to season your 14 part dish.
Of a dominator, using magic and intimidation to force great, great beasts under your control.
Of a glassblower, making vials to sell.
Of an alchemist, concocting potions to heal, or kill. Become renown for your potency, or keep humble.
Of a racist human woman who robs and kills all non-humans.
Of a thick, righteous half-breed who protects their home at all costs, otherwise docile.
Of a maniac axe murderer, unable to resist killing all they meet.

Of... just about anything or anyone you can imagine! Create your own builds, take some skills from different tree's and blend, suit your character to your own playstyle, whatever that may be.

If you're content playing alone, you can kill hours on this game, doing your own modest thing.
If you're into grouping up and having fun, you can kill days on this game with a nice guild.
If you're into politics, drama and war, you can kill months on this game with a big guild.

This game has something for everyone.

TL;DR:
Give the game an hour or two to hook you and adjust you to the small bugs and imperfections, and you'll never need another game again. Do what you want, when you want, however you want. I've been doing just that for three years now.

10/10

reviewText: Love this game. You NEED to have patience and a thick skin. When other reviews talk about the abundance of player killing, they're not lying. Keep your wits about you, even when you think no ones around. With patience, it is very possible to become self sustaining in the game, but there will ALwAYS be a player better than you. I don't necessarily think you HAVE to have a guild to get anywhere (although it helps), making friends is good enough and I've found more pleasant players than not so far. Just make sure you are making the right friends. If you die, you WILL lose everything. When traveling long distances, travel lightly and with stuff you can afford to lose. Keep items in reserve at banks in every city you come to, when applicable. (Cause you never know where you're going to die. This helps you not be completely without when entering a city) For new players: stay in help chat as long as you can. It is beneficial. I believe the new update allows it to be up for a week now. Overall, positive review here. Easy to get lost and diving in for hours at a time.

reviewText:
It feels like I'm playing the early beta to the greatest Ultima-clone ever made. And thats what bother me the most about it, how the game feels like it's still very early in development despite the fact it's been around for years. That, and the fact it's virtually impossible to level up skills in the starting zones because people will immediately rush up to stand between you and whatever youre trying to hit, causing the guards to come after you and get you killed so they can take all your ♥♥♥♥.

I can see soooo much potential in this game, and yet just like a lot of MMOs lately, fails to become what they could be. And it's essentially paywalling you from ever experiencing the full game, especially since free accounts have a maximum skill level of 60, meaning that paying players will always have an advantage over free players...which is the very definition of pay 2 win".

It's worth a try
date: but I can't recommend this game to somebody who is looking for a time investment. It's fun to ♥♥♥♥ around in for a while but not much more than that
recommended: and don't let the fanboys bully you in to it with their "You're just not hard-core enough" schtick. I love me a good hardcore RPG...i just don't love THIS hardcore rpg.\n"

reviewText: Wanted to get into this game because there are supposedly some elements that are really appealing to me.... reviewText:
I found this game on twitch and was hooked before i knew it was on steam. i had a 6 month sub before i downloaded it.  Then to find out its a small team of Delvs that has done all this its kind of mind blowing. 4-5 guys built this vs 100s of ppl on other games just to make landscape.

This game reminds me of world of warcraft 2003. before it was nerfed into the ground.

A. It has one of the largest crafting systems i have seen in a game.

B. The combat is unlike other mmo's and can take a few days or weeks to really learn how to fight (like CSGO vs other FPS you have to learn how to use the weapon).

C. You can write books. make ingame maps/armor/weapon's/poitons. breed horses or other mounts to use to sell and so much more.

D. Its a mix between Eve/Elderscrolls/WoW/ and medieval warfar.

It does have some bugs and node lines but hey i dont fall past the ground and get stuck for 2hrs like wow 2003. when the game lets out a patch it does not forget to add something i need for a month like BC. i have not seen all black mob without any color just a shape like Naxx at 60.

Hands down one of the best games i have found in a very long time. only thing i see holding it back it the player base both in greefing new players(something you have to get past then its not a big thing) and in the money a larger player base would bring so the Delv team could hire more ppl and roll out updates.

Explore/be a highway man and rob ppl/ build huge keeps and citys/ Find something that no other player has found share it or keep it secret its up to you, this game has so many sides of play it even has fishing you pick bait,line,hooks, how deep you cast it.

If you enjoy a harder style of game with a amazing crafting system and are stick of all the pathed games being made anymore then this is for you. its a world not a 16man Q or sitting in town waiting for a Q to pop for you.

Oh and the game has heart it just ban a full guild AiM for cheating thats why you see so many angry posts about the game.  Game >  $$  thank you very much Delvs.

reviewText: The game was fun in the beginning, you feel like you can do anything, by anything I mean something along the lines of sit in the new player zone where pigs are and command guards to attack the pigs while another is simply trying to do the tutorial or grind leather for crafting. reviewText:
Don't let the rating decieve you. This game is spectacular, but it sure as hell isn't for everyone. I've played this game for 5 years since beta, and I have seen all kinds of players: they either try it and drop it, or they play it and stay forever.  If you're the first kind, you're probably going to hate the game with a passion and wonder why on earth people play it in the first place. If you're the second, however, you will be hooked. Possibly forever (like me). There is nothing out on the market that fills the niche like Mortal. Below are some more details about the game.

PROS AND CONS:

+ Open world action RPG with real-time directional combat.
+ Combat is easy to learn, difficult to master.
- Mechanics can be dodgy and frustrating at times.

+ Interesting race system and a sprawling skill tree with multiple branches a la Morrowind on drugs
+ Palpable sense of progression.
+ Skill up by doing (like in the Elder Scrolls Series) and by reading skill books (like EvE).
-  Can be slow and grindy.
-  While you can make very diverse builds, only a few are typically accepted as competent, with the rest being 'gimped.'

+ PvP is exciting.
+ Can give you shivers and make your palms sweat when you enter your first large scale battle.
+ (or -) While there are no traditional 'classes' in the game, there are distinct roles that can be filled such as 'footfighter,' 'mounted combat,' 'mage' or 'hybrid mage.'
- There are some issues with balance and lag.

+ Crafting system is neat and intuitive.
+ Combine many different materials and parts to make new and customized armor and weapons.
-  Proper crafting requires maxed skills, material lores and a subscription.
-  Can take a long time and a lot of gold/materials to become a competent crafter (depending on the profession).

+ PvE can be fun and unique.
+ Action based combat with timed blocks and aiming.
- Timing can be wonky.
- Can get repetitive quickly if you don't like it.
+ Some interesting mechanics in the tougher enemies such as Demons, Minos and half the mobs in Sarducca.
- (or +) First time you get jumped by a monster in Sarducca, you might poop a little.

+ The game requires extensive  interaction with the community for the full experience.
- It's an awful community.
+ It's a wonderful awful community.

reviewText:
Mortal Online.

It is no suprise to me that this game has around a 50% approval rating because that is exactly what it endeavors itself to receive. Really it is the perfect score. Not because its bad but because of the world of Mortal Online it self. The world is full of freedom, oprtunities and most of all merciless DEATH. With a full loot system so it is very taxing and difficult to get into at first. But if you stay strong and realize the freedom, fun and adventure this game has got to offer that possibly no other game does, you may find what you were looking for. But it can definately be to much to take for alot of people. So 50% approval is 100% of what the game and its community is intending to recieve and they got what they were after.

Now for my review.

(I played the game for about 6 months straight in 2014)

Well first off I love that the world and the quests and the storys are not told by NPC's but by the players them selves. If you think moral decisions really mean alot in games like Fable or Fallout then you have not tasted Mortal Online. Everything you do matters to someone else. Every good thing you do for someone and every nasty wicked thing you do means ALOT to another person. When you get into a guild, make friends, get involved in the politics of the world it self; you are fighting for what ever you are for, evil or good, money or power and everything you do matters and effects someone else. And passions and tensions definately rise all of the time. Theres really no other game that i have ever played before that really felt like a 2nd life like the experience that Mortal Online gives you. So I absolutely love that.

The combat system is pretty good. Not the best ive ever seen and but definately not the worst. It is skill based and you can not target your oppenent like in other mmo's. Im not a big fan of the way you fire off magic spells in this game but eh, alot of people make it work for them and I suppose if you can you may enjoy that too. But the combat is more like Chivalry.

The crafting system and the skill leveling system really shine the brightest. There is so much depth and originality in both of these 2 systems that Mortal Online really made it their own and no other game has before or sense done anything like it and I really admire them alot. So epic. Quite possibly the best part.

The bad. The bugs and glitches can be a real pain in the a$$ sometimes. I mean really. I know the community told the dev's they should have focused on fixing the bugs and glitchs before they focused on saraducaa but they did not listen. Honostly as much as I love the game it self for what it is the bugs and glitchs kill it for actually making it on the list of my most favorite games of all time. But it is still top 10.

Overall I would give this game and 8.4 out of 10. It loses .2 points for the community being alittle to a-holey to noobs but at the same time Mortal Needs those a-holes in endgame to make the world go round so hard to balance the a-holeness and it loses the other -1.2 because of the bugs and glitches. The dev team needs to stop focusing on growth and expansion and focus on pest control. The bugs need a fix for real. But other then that I ABSOLUTELY recomend this game. It is as if Ultima Online and The Elder Scrolls (not online) series had a baby with its own sense of identity and flare. And those 2 games are my favorite of all time. So for that I love Mortal Online.

<3

reviewText:
There's a lot of mixed reviews and there's very good reasons for this, the game is not everyone's cup of tea and you can tell when first logging in that it's a very difficult game to get into. I feel like if more people gave the game the time it deserved and didn't judge based on first impressions it wouldn't have anywhere near as many negative reviews.

Pros
Be anything you want
Awesome combat
Hugely diverse playstyles
Full loot PvP
Meainingful alignment system
Territorial control
World building
Creature control via taming/domination
Tons of things to discover
F2P, try it and if you don't like it who cares?

Cons
Sub is an absolute requirement to play the game effectively
Extremely steep learning curve
Very difficult barrier of entry
Small amounts of information available(is a pro if you enjoy learning things yourself)
Creating a gimped character can affect how effective you are in which role you choose(google templates for whatever you plan to play)
Lots of griefing in main cities(blue blocking etc to make you flag criminal)
Game is open world so you get lag" once you hit server loading lines
date: since you have to load the area of the world and all creatures/players/structures that are there\n\nI have played MO on and off for a few years and never stuck around longer than a week
recommended: the game has improved massively and I'm having trouble logging out since I started playing a few days ago."

reviewText: It's an interesting concept, but there too many issues to look past it like you would DayZ or similar games.\n\nThe biggest issues are the combat, movement, what I would call wealth/character progression"
date:
and the disingenuous f2p mechanic.

Combat

- Combat has an odd "charge your swing" mechanic. You basically have to hold your swing back for 1 or 2 seconds before you'll do max damage. It really slows the game down
recommended: and makes it a bit finicky because there's no animation to tell when you've fully charged your weapon. You just have to know.\n\n- As a new player you don't even have the ability to see how much damage you've done. You need a skill called damage assessment
hoursPlayed: but even with the skill you still won't be able to see how much damage you do because your skills are limited to 60. It needs to be higher than that to get an exact number. So the only way for a new player OR f2p to figure how how long they need to charge is to guestimate based on the health bar of your target. Pay to see your damage is kind of lame.\n\n- Your block doesn't drop immediately after you release the block. It hangs for a second
voteText: so you have to wait a whole second after you drop your block to respond. Otherwise you'll push your enemy instead of attack them. The community in game was very unhelpful explaining this. Some of them told me that I needed to get the block skills up to change this
helpfulPercent: and others told me that I simply had a horrible connection. I looked through the skill tree
votesHelpful: and I didn't see anything to reduce it. So I think it's connection related.\n\n- Everything is delayed. I take damage and the game doesn't recognize it quick enough. I fell off a building
votesTotal: and It took 3 seconds for the game to register I took damage. An enemy swings on my screen
votesFunny: and I take no damage
commentsCount: then 2 seconds later I'll take the damage. It's just weird
column16: and it's impossible to fight well if you don't know if you're being hit or not.\n\n- P2P characters have a meaningful damage and damage reduction lead on F2P characters. Since P2P characters can max their skills they get the full bonuses from aggressive and defensive stance
column17: but a f2p gets very little. I asked the community about scaling
column18: and the player base told me that skill bonuses operate on an exponential curve. So 60 - 80 does twice as much as 1 - 60
column19: and 80 - 100 does the most.\n\n- In general it just has an odd floaty feel to it
column20:
and it isn't super interesting. You could just play chivalry.

Movement

- As a new player your character starts extremely slow. It's like you're scooting around as an old lady. You'll need to raise your attributes to go quicker. It's a VERY annoying start
column21: and someone in /h suggested that I just go afk chopping wood to raise my attributes. I did that
column22: and it was a big help in making me enjoy the game.\n\n- As a f2p every p2p character is going to be faster than you. There's no way for you chase a p2p character down
column23: or escape from a p2p character. It's literally just it. Movement skills operate the same way as defensive and aggressive stance. You're not getting 60% of the skill bonuses when you get it to level 60. It's more like 35 - 40%. It's a huge gain for the p2p character.\n\n- There's an odd double tap mechanic. So if you double tap a direction key twice you'll do a double jump. The problem is that it's inconsistent with the sensitivity. For example
column24: I quickly did ADAA
column25: and it gave me a long jump to the left. Then I repeatedly clicked AAAAAA and it wasn't giving me the long jump. It's very easy to make the mistake of accidentally doing a long jump in combat
column26: and there is also no way to change the sensitivity
column27:
so it is what it is. I think the devs need to drop the double tap and make it a simple modified action. For example CTRL + directional key should do the long jump.

Wealth progression!

- Basically the game has a very simple progression in the beginning. You spawn in
column28: do the tutorial
column29: then you go to the graveyard and kill zombies to raise your attributes and collect zombie heads to sell and buy books. Once you're strong enough you go into the sewer and you kill scoundrels to do the exact same thing. It's fairly boring
column31: AND sometimes the AI has long ranged attacks that will hit you through walls and pillars. It's just not fun or engaging.\n\n- You can buy gear
column33: and food from other players on a broker. It's not really intuitive what is good or not
column34: and the sorting on the broker doesn't really work. For example I searched weapons
column35: and the first thing on the list was a cooking pot. Also the economy seems fairly dead.\n\n- You can also build your own house
column36: but I don't really see the point in doing that. The community basically told me that it's "cool"
column37: but it doesn't seem like there's an ingame reason for players to have a personal house. You can do everything in the major city.\n\nSo basically you would do the initial stuff
column40:
and then you wouldn't really have any use for your money.

f2p

- It's not a f2p game. I get the feeling they tacked on f2p for marketing reasons
column41: but they never designed coherent mechanics around it. You can call it pay to win. If they're insistent that it's f2p then I would call it pay to win
column42: but otherwise it's just a subscription game with a glorified trial.\n\nIt's frankly a fairly mediocre game that has a lot of content
column43: but it didn't do anything well. I would pay to play it if it was a $5 sub
column44: but they want $14 so it I don't think it's worth it."

reviewText:
First off its been a bit since i last played and this time around im having the same feelings as i did when the game launchedA New Hope" a while back i pre-ordered the game played alot in the beginning befor my computer had optimization issues with Mortal online and other games now this time around my computer can handle Mortal online alot better then befor.

Now lets get into the game play its a real time action based combat system MMO in third person view it's Ultima Onlines Successor It has pretty decent graphics depending on what setting your playing on even on the lowest setting it still is pretty decent.The characters/ environment and mounts buildings and terrain all look amazing for being 4-5 years old.

Combat System 10/10*
-----------------
Real time action based
*WARNING* There is no carebear mechanics in combat meaning noones there to hold your hand.

The combat system is "REALISTIC" you actually have to "AIM" and "CHARGE" your attacks the longer your attacks are charged the more damage youll deal or lets say your a archer you have your bow and arrows and you see a enemy you actually have to aim your target cursor to where your enemy is and charge it depending on how far or how much damage you want to deal.
-----------------


Crafting  9/10*
---------
Similar to Ultima onlines crafting

The crafting is pretty cool sorta similar to Ultima online you have a forge and crafting tables theres various ores or marterials to be collected to be crafted into something unusual and unique.I havnt tested the crafting out fully so i cant really say much else.

----------

PVE
---------
Various Npc's to be farmed and harvested for materials or for trade to other players wish there were dragons though been wanting to see them in game for quit some time.

---------

PVP
---------
In my honest opinion one of the best PVP mechanics ive seen in a while it takes skill and tactical plans to defeat someone not for hand holding.

Overall i rate Mortal online 10/10 for for its diverse unique third person MMO combat/skilling/crafting/pve/and pvp

"

reviewText:
Make no mistake- the game is subscription based, not really F2P.
You will have a permanent free to play account; Just bare in mind it will not be as good in any aspect of the game as the premium one (your skills will be locked at lvl 60 instead of 100)and some functions (IE thievery) will be simple disabled for you.
Other than that it is worth a try.
Things worth noting:
-a small team, and that is reflected in the speed stuff changes/improves in the game.
-full loot ffa pvp with no real safe zones (enter at your own risk)
-twitch based combat
-no classic levels. Instead a skill system reminiscent of games like Morrowind or Ultima Online.
-quite a few interesting things to do, from taming and thievery, to building player towns.
-FPV only and with good reasons.
-Quite a few small glitches and bugs.

reviewText:
First of all this game is not for feint of hearted. This is true PvP! The land of Mortal Online is harsh and violent. Even in starting city after few hours of gameplay you are vulnerable to other players. There are thiefs that try to steal your hard earned money. There are players who do anything to scam you out. And if you wander too far from the city guards you can be a victim of cold blooded murderers.

But within this hard world there is also unity and friendship. When the world is harsh you need to rely on friends and mates. Strenght comes from numbers. You can form guilds with your new or old friends or join any of the existing ones. There are guilds that do PvP battles, Crafting and trading, and even Thiefs have their own player guild for you to join.

So you can choose any path that you want. Be it hero or villain. Mortal online offers you the chance to play as you like.

But be warned. Be prepared to lose all your har earned loot if you are not smart enough. This game definetly brings out emotions. Good and Bad.

But when you succeed the rewarding feeling is so great!

reviewText:
I have been playing Mortal Online now for approximately 4 months now, 200+ hours, and can say this game has the raw hardcore feeling I havent fealt since vanilla WoW. (not saying this game is anything like WoW mind you)
Now here is what i have to say about the game.

This game is not for casual gaming, this game is very time consuming lots of grinding, to be efficient/competitive you need to have a subscription and possibly multiple characters. Ya i know free to play" The free to play aspect of the game lets you play but with limited skills. Which its meant that you play the game to see if you like it or not.

I give this game a Positive review because its what I want out of an MMO. Its hardcore takes time but is rewarding when you do accomplish your goals (much like how Vanilla WoW was.) There isnt handholding from the game its a steep learning curve. On my list the Cons do out number the Pros but the Cons are very rewarding.



Pros:
Hardcore game/loot (If you die you drop all your loot on the ground)
Open world
PvP
Guilds
Territory control
Resource control


Cons:
Slow updates (The development team is really small so updates are far and few between but they do happen)
Small player base (steam release helped game a little but lack of handholding for new players made a lot quit)
Guild politics (most major guilds are allied and at stand stills so it limits guild PvP)
Greifing new players
Low skill point system (you wont be able to do multiple classes on one character to maximum efficiency forcing you to have multiple character slots)
Known bugs not being fixed
Not new user friendly (took me a couple days to figure it out)

"

reviewText:
This game was great. I played a while ago and am very happy to see it on steam. Although some of the negative reviews are true it does not change that the game is still at least worth you trying it out. I'll give you the TLDR: First.

Pros:
Nearly infinite freedom
Can play however you want to play
Lots of nice players willing to help new players
The trailer doesn't portray anything that the game is not
Extremely complex pvp system
Payment is optional

Cons:
Extremely complex pvp system
Not a jump in and run style game
Everything takes lots of time to do and train
High system spec requirements
Payment allows user to train skills from 60 to 100 (only viable f2p build is hybrid)
You find yourself very lost as soon as you leave the city

To play the game to its fullest you must have a good computer and a subscription. Being solo is very difficult unless you have an extensive knowlege of the combat system and great timing. That being said with a small group or a lot of training this game can be among the best you have played since (for many of you) UO. Same skill type system, you can do everything yourself. Nearly everything is player made. Trial and error will be your friend when crafting.

I never take the time to write reviews, but I feel like this game was unjustly charged a mixed" rating. If you like the feel of the elder scrolls and the openness of a sandbox game. Give this a shot (computer allowing). Most issues players report for negative reviews are because they play on toasters that cannot support anything beyond the dated requirements World of Warcraft still supports. To those people (I appologize in advance) WoW is not a standard for MMO's anymore
date: it is time for an upgrade."

reviewText:
Got muted from the help chat for asking what to do with zombie heads and got murdered about 2-3 times by different people within the timespan of an hour in a newbie zone. Worst part?

They all used loopholes that have existed in this game for years on end to both avoid guards altogether (immediate armed retaliation) and the game design intended consequences of RDMing people (flagging system) continues being an overly complicated, useless mess that does absolutely nothing but slightly spank people that go on multiple mass slaughters within a short period of time.

The community can sometimes be considered decent with a few good souls here and there but It's almost entirely made up of toxic man-children, griefers and trolls that currently flourish from doing things like I've stated above.

Combine that with some incredibly clunky combat mechanics and a horrendously deep & unexplained learning curve and you've got yourself an MMO you're better off avoiding.

reviewText: This game is awesome big learning curve and very little direction but once you get used to the game you will understand why. The game is very open and leaves alot up to the player. THERE ARE NO QUEST IN THIS GAME. I want to make that clear for any new players that try to enter this as a normal MMo everything is player driven. Even some cites are player controled. This is an open loot game like Elder scrolls or Fallout, so when you die anyone can loot everything you have in your bags. The one thing this game lacks is PvE but StarVault has been adding more and more PvE. I have been enjoying some of the duingeons in the game and can't wait to see more. The game map is massive and the banks are not linked to each other so if you have gear in one city you will have to go to that city to get it. There is just so much in thius game that gets over looked and I say give it a try I highly recommand it for anyone that is looking for a hardcore first person MMO. There is also gore and full nudity that adds to the overall feel of the game, which is overlooked and many games like this. Thius game is free to play but I like to call it an unlimited trial for the simple fact that your skills are limited to 60, granted you can lvl them to 100 but only 60 will be used until you sub.

reviewText:
Came back after 4 months of a break (played before the steam release) and can say the game improved a little. They are still clunky, but at least the DDOS attacks have been sorted out :P

And seriously - I had tons of fun in this game. Due to some problems that made me waste 2 weeks of a paid subscription (had to work, couldn't play, right after paying) I lost interest since it got me really disappointed. I came back solely to recommend this game, since it's scores on steam a soaring.

It's a clunky, niche, small-team developed mmo, but you're gonna have tons of fun with it if you are already bored with the AAA titles (or - the title :P). Other mmos are more polished, but all of them have the same gameplay. As a former wow raider I cannot bring myself to play the clones or go thru the same (only reskinned) dungeon to see the same set of bosses' moves I saw 2 years before.

It's just that simple guys - bored with everything else? At least try Mortal - it can be enjoyable! You died? People die in wow too. Look at this exactly the same way.

Will the game improve further? I sure hope so. If I didn't I wouldn't recommend the game as it is now. There's hope for me because the steam release is still fresh, which means the devs can still reforge this money into more development.

If you, for some reason, want to visit my blog from the time I played mortal regularly (will hope to be able to do it): https://mortalonlineandme.wordpress.com/ is the web page. Enjoy. I tried to be funny despite my broken english.

Try the game out with an open mind. What's out there to loose but time? There are countless ♥♥♥♥♥♥, bland games that will take plenty of that from you.

reviewText:
Really a great game, certainly very buggy in some points still besides being available since 2010(?).

But there are not many games like this, with open PVP, and full-loot with no levels. There is a skill system where you need to specialize your character into a certain build with about 1100 possible skill points. Some skills are secondary and do not use this pool.

The game has a steep-learning curve, and the ability to be killed outside any major towns (and even within, but the person usually does not get away with it) may put new players off. But everybody dies. Money is as easy as farming NPC mobs which can be dull, but its not difficult.

Combat is rewarding and also hard to learn, but this is not a casual's game.

There is a decent sized population of players most who have been playing the game for quite some time.

8/10 cause of bugs. The game is built by a very small team, I only hope that they can improve it more in the future.

reviewText:
PROS:
+ refreshing skill and crafting mechanics
+ friendly devs, often in game talking in the chat
+ sometimes friendly players, that dont kill you as soon as they see you, despite the full PvP loot system (if You get killed they can they everything You had, only the items in the bank are safe)
+ no global bank, well this seems realistic

CONS:
- the world is BIG and often appears to be empty
- game has severe performance issues (low FPS, stuttering or even freezing), and the problem is not on my end, my computer runs games with higher system requirements than this game flawlessly
- bad bussiness model, at least for my taste, with monthly subscription fees in the range of 14 - 12 euros per month, it is too much even for an AAA title (take a look at how Elder Scrolls Online went from subscribtions to a Buy to Play model), if that monthly fee, they want, would be a one time payment I might reconsider it
- severely limited F2P, skill cap for free players for all skills at 60 / 100 skillpoints is almost halving the skills of the free players, THAT is really not what a F2P game does (I am okay with the guild stuff and the land owning being only for premiums)

VERDICT:
I dont care about the graphics, I would gladly play it with completely crappy graphics like if it was 15 years old, But the technical state of the game (severe performance issues) and the current bussiness model (14 - 12 euros per month subscribtion, or play for free with all skills capped at 60/100) is killing it. The devs should be right now grateful to players playing it, reporting bugs and helping to polish, such an unpolished game.

reviewText:
EDIT:
One of the long-time players has contacted me and mentioned that there are player cities that exist that are much safer than the starting cities.  Their guild would be happy to move me to a safe city if I recreate a character.   The game mechanics and abilities were fun so I'm going to give it another shot and see if it works better.  More to come in a few weeks.....

-------------------------

The mechanics are a nod back to traditional skill based mmos, graphics are nice and I had a decent time in the tutorial zone.

However, it has the typical toxic player base that prefers to grief using PvP mechancis and exploits to actually playing the PvE portion of the game.

In fact, the rules that are in place to stop player killing in towns actually raises griefing to an artform in Mortal Online.

My first experience with a griefer was when they charmed an animal then then left it standing alone in a field of other animals of the same type.  Waiting until a newbie player like me attacks it (not knowing that it counts as an attack on a player if you attack their pets).  And thus I was KOS by the guards, quickly murdered and then taunted for my newb" mistake.

My second experience with griefing came when I left the newbie zone.   There's always a "welcoming committee" of PKers waiting just a little ways outside the zone entrance to make sure you get welcome-murdered.  From talking to higher level players
