reviewText:
Let me begin by saying that I've followed Mortal Online since its conception and that I have always been madly in love with the potential/concept of what the game could have been.

Meager Proof: http://i.imgur.com/SyuxQpd.png

Key Overview of Mortal Online:

- Firstly, Mortal Online was released OVER FIVE YEARS ago. So anyone trying to call out a negative review based off of the playtime shown on Steam is completely misguided.

-The fact that it was created five years ago also stands as a testimony to how horribly, horribly directed the game has been this entire time.

- It began under the development of a small group of Swedish guys who created their little independent company Star Vault, and because I have not been following it that closely, I'm not entirely sure how much they've grown since then. I'm relatively positive that the dev team is still quite diminutive especially given the scope of the game and its current state. Again, that is speculation.

This game was a project loaded with potential, but got corrupted by a small, dedicated playerbase who refused to acknowledge the actual problems with the game and kept feeding the egos of blind, prideful developers. Five years into this virulent cycle, the independent company gets to release their game on Steam to a wave of people who are unfamiliar with the long standing unhealthy cycle that has been going on for ages.

So, in good conscience, I cannot recommend this game. They need to learn a lesson. This type of independent company behavior is not okay and should not be encouraged.

------THIS IS THE END OF THE CORE OVERVIEW STOP HERE BEFORE TL;DR REVIEW BELOW------

I'm going to do a LOOSE FORM of a pros and cons list to come off as unbiased as I can towards this game, because, as mentioned above, I really did have the highest of hopes for it fulfilling my wildest MMO fantasies. It, unfortunately, clearly has no intentions of ever rising up to meet its potential or making the required changes to fulfill said fantasies.

That being said, expect a more descriptive list of cons as this is still a NEGATIVE review.

This WILL NOT be comprehensive at the time of writing, because I simply don't have the time and I could go on endlessly about the good ideas and the horrible implementations that this game suffers from.

Pros:

- The world's big, fascinating, and a mystery for every new player to discover with minimal guidance.

- The game's mechanics are hardcore and there is no hand-holding going on here. It's really an amazing design philosophy that I love to embrace.

- The idea of a true open sandbox where you can literally be whatever you want to be is there. Trader by day, highwayman by night. Valiant defender of justice, or rapscallion rogue pickpocketing in the streets. You decide.

- The concept of real time combat with responsive and individual body-part hitboxes in an MMO is astounding.

Cons:

- Several of the systems, the mechanics, are still as severely flawed as they were five years ago at release. For instance, the flagging system. (Which indicates whether you've been a good or naughty person in the game world recently. Blue flag means innocent, grey flag means you've done something bad and you're free game, red flag means you're murderous scum and can be killed on sight) It was never refined to a logical point and I'll give the roughest example for people who haven't played the game yet. Let's say I'm killing some NPC creatures and I'm flagged blue. A person can, literally, run like a madman in between the monster and me so that I accidentally hit them. When I accidentally hit them, the game flags me grey and I become free game for that person and anyone else around to attack me since I'm now considered a criminal. I don't know the timer on it, which brings me to my next point.

- There is no consistent, well documented data for... Anything really. Monsters, towns, maps, items, basic functionality. In game, it's almost nonexistent except for some vague descriptions here and some weak tutorials that are pretty much only presented within the first thirty minutes of the game. The playerbase is so small and tight-knit that you can't even find reliable, recent online documentation for things. The TWO Wiki resources have blank pages or pages that haven't been updated in years. This ties into the next point.

- The game's mechanics are hardcore and there is no hand-holding going on here. While it's a really amazing design philosophy, it's not an excuse to justify lazy, badly executed design. That seems to be a go-to argument for the game's supporters. What they fail to realize is that peoples' qualms lie less so in the game being hardcore" and moreso in it feeling unpolished or just... lazy. An example in my next point.

- This is supposed to be an established fantasy world with a lore and history
date: but... You don't even have access to ANY in-game map? You're telling me that the inhabitants of this massive world
recommended: these people who built countless intricate cities... Never drew up maps? I'm not even asking for a marker on the map of where I'm at. I'm asking for just a simple map alone for reference. Even a map that fills in as you explore it would make more sense than this. The lack of systems
hoursPlayed: the lack of designs for these systems. It's blatant and people who defend it using the
voteText: "You just can't handle how hardcore the game is" allow the developers to get away with bad design choices.\n\n- The idea of "Free To Play" is extremely misguiding here. All the skills in the game have a cap of 100. If you're a FTP player
helpfulPercent: however
votesHelpful: you can only level up any skill to 60. Explaining this in the simplest of math
votesTotal: it makes you effectively 40% less efficient than any subscriber and bars you off from doing a great many things in the game or reaching high level content. That should be absolutely all I need to say about this.\n\n- 14 dollars for a month's subscription? That's ludicrous. World of Warcraft/Blizzard earned the right to charge people 15 bucks a month. Absolutely ludicrous
votesFunny: especially when Star Vault's idea of "Free To Play" really means "Unlimited Trial period".\n\n- The bugs and glitches this far along... Are unforgivable. Items jumping back from your bank to your inventory when you log off. Items disappearing from the bank altogether. Cumbersome rubberbanding when fighting NPC monsters. The list goes on infinitely."

reviewText:
I see many reviews complaining about things that are neither good od bad but simply part of the concept.
Complaining about losing everything you carry when killed in a full loot game is like down voting star wars because you find spaceships boring.

This game is a full loot, full pvp, first person fantasy sandbox.

Another regular in bad reviews is the claim that it is p2w.
It is not. It is simply p2p. Consider f2p as a kind of demo. You get to play the game and do almost everything there is in it, just nothing very well. Can you create the uber solo pvp warrior as an f2p? No, but that would be weird wouldn't it?
This game does not keep afloat offerin cosmetic micro-transactions like real f2p games but also not through micro-transactions giving real advantage like a p2w. In fact, there are no micro-transactions at all. This game makes it's money with player subscriptions and among those everyone is equal and nobody can buy an advantage.

This game is certainly unpolished, experiences lag, bugs and glitches but they are all while numerous, rather minor.

It makes up for it with the same aspects that are difficult to grasp for many new players, including me:
The players have to explore the world themselves. There is no in game map. Equiptment stats are never explicitely revealed. Players are given an approximaton of their different gear items' stats the accuracy of which depends on their skills with the various item types.
All of this plus the lack of quests telling you what to do next is frustrating to many expecting another game similar to what they have played before. You simply have to keep going and find a purpose for yourself in this world.
Join a guild and carve out your piece of it. Don't expect you and your 2 other f2p friends can just start the game and after 5 hours walk into an established guild's territory and take their stuff. If you could, something would be very wrong.

Give it a try. If you find something really wrong, write a bad review but please, don't do it simply because you'd prefer this game to be less free.

reviewText:
Mortal Online will have momments where you smile a smile of peer joy, just to have that smile wiped of your face by a random player who saw you heading towards town. They will attack you and probably kill you for no reason other than to see what loot you had or just to prove their better then someone new to the game i guess.
While the Game itself has one of the best concepts and a decent excution of a full loot sandbox many players will find it to frustrating to  really enjoy. The community is aweful, the worst i have ever experienced in any game i have ever played. Just look at the forumns and youll get an idea of what im talking about. Thats not to say everyone playing mortal is aweful, but 60%of players will kill you just to kill you and 85% will kill you if they think it will get them good loot.
I have come to enjoy the game over all for the momments when that player that attacked you bit of more then they can chew or when you stumble on a robbery in progress just in time to turn the battle into a win for the innocent. This game isnt for everyone. Heck, its not going to be for most but few hardcore games are.
PROS
*Combat system is both fun and skill" really can help.
*Every interaction with a player is exciting.
*Player driven economy/world
*Really cool and refreshing skills gaining mechanic( you have to use it to get better)
*Havent done much crafting myself but there is really awesome depth to it.
CONS
*Full loot means a death can set you back hours..
*The Community is aweful
*There are still exploits
*Blue blocking ( This is when a player jumps infront of your attack so you hit them
date:
now they can kill you with out being a murder.)

Overall
This game is fun but its def not for everyone but its free to try and if you like it Sub because your not gonna make it if you dont."

reviewText:
It..sort of feels like an incomplete Morrowind, Skyrim, Runescape MMO all cobbled together with duct-tape, black magic and inside swedish jokes. Its not a BAD game persay, it has two large continents and a recent large patch which I've yet to explore much. The community is mostly made of up either guild politicts and drama or just your average rampant murderers (Which are some guilds). I like this game, I really do, though it just feels, incomplete, empty, without content.
I'd really like to see some major updating to this game, some actual house decor and even perhaps minor terraforming? Please, let me make my little beach side cactii garden in Sarducaa. You're definitely going to want to team up with friends and even a guild to accomplish anything above farming some pigs and skeletans for your life in here.

Its playable mostly, it can be quite a good bit of fun at times. Its largely dependant on the adventures you go on with your friends if anything. You can play for /free/ but are limited to a cap on your skills from 100 to 60. It might not seem like that big of a deal, though when that elf mage that's running faster than the speed of light is doing 40% more damage than yours, then you'll understand. l'm recommending TRYING it for now, grab a one month sub if you find yourself in a lovely little guild like I did. Make your own goals and ever pursue them, don't become too disappointed when you get killed and lose your items.

reviewText:
Alright, I previously had a bad review on this game.

What can I say? The first impressions were less than great, especially when I couldn't log in the game for any apparent reason for months.
Oddly enough, the next day after posting that review, suddenly I'm able to log on. Coincidence?



So, after actually getting to play and experience the game, here's what I have to say:

First, I'm sincerely glad I gave it another try. The experience of this game is like none other, that's the truth.

The world of Nave is a bittersweet landscape, a twist of beauty and terror. You can explore EVERYTHING, you can FIGHT everything. However, EVERYTHING is DANGEROUS.

Swimming is dangerous, pvp is hell, standing in a desert or blizzard is deadly, your friends are deadly, the city guards are out to get you if you aren't careful.      This game should be titled:  50000 ways to die in an MMO.

The enivronment is gorgeous.  The land is huge, the water is breath-taking (literally), the sky is awespiring, the cities are quite regal (Though I wish we could enter more buildings than a bank.) The Music is very attractive and helps you connect to the game.

The combat system is an amazement. Some people say it's basic and boring,  I say it's quite tactical.  In WoW you can macro everything you want to do to a single key-press and spam it.   In Mortal Online, you have to AIM for weak spots with your weapon.   The combat of this game is more engaging than ANY I have encountered, even in console single-player games.

The major downside of this game is that the community is very, very toxic. I recommend finding a guild as soon as possible to help remedy this. (Shout out to my HERO friends!) After joining the HERO guild, they immediately took me under-wing, taught me more about the game and have been very patient with me.


There are some limitations to the game for free to play players.  However with enough skill, know-how, and knowledge of the game itself and what gear it has to offer, a F2p can go toe-to-toe with a P2p any day. It's all about reaction time and accuracy.

Soon I will begin toying around with construction, we'll see how that goes.

Apologies to the developers for my harsh words on my first review of this game, (frankly it was deserved with 2 months of unavailable play.)  But it's okay. The game speaks for itself, and I'm glad I get to be a part of it.

Keep doing what you do, StarVault.

reviewText:
As of Sept 1, 2015, getting connected is a huge pain (likely due to a large influx of people for this game's debut on Steam).  The usual out-of-the-gate hiccups for an unprepared development/server management team are prevalent.  Likely 2-3 weeks before stability issues are resolved - an average estimate for this increasingly common problem with games nowadays.  Early Access, I can understand, but this game has been available for some time even prior to the Steam Release

In its current state:

Pros:

1) Some veteran players are genuinely helpful (kudos to those who are answering the seemingly endless requests for help on the very first newbie quest.)  Admittedly, it took me a few minutes to figure out what to do, This is one game where reading the quest text as it is given is crucial.

2) Decent graphics.  Unreal Engine always offers a good bang for the buck in graphics capabilities.

3) Free to Play - although, skill levels are capped at 60 (out of 100) and there are skills that are not accessible to F2P players (Thievery)

Cons:

1) Getting connected successfully is (at best) random; might be better late at night when player base decreases

2) Widespread reports on logging out, then attempting to login only to receive a message stating you are already logged in"; research on the game's forums indicate this issue only goes away after a server restart - lovely

3) Murdering is pretty rampant - higher level players are genuinely bored enough to travel all the way to the cities where the new influx of players are spawing just to kill low level characters just outside the city limits (that's actually a pretty good indication of how boring end-game must be
date: as there's absolutely no material benefit in doing this other than to just be a PK'er)\n\n4) Latency issues; again
recommended: indicative of poor initial scalability on the server-end of things
hoursPlayed: but will iron itself out over time (in the short term
voteText: because of player loss; new players are very likely to lose interest from not being able to advance their characters without getting murdered constantly by high level players)\n\nI will update this review once I re-test after a couple of weeks to see if the server issues have been ironed out.  If you want to check it out to see for youself
helpfulPercent: go for it.  It has some interesting concepts.  There's no way I'd recommend it right now - there's some things they need to get under control fast before this influx of Steam players makes their decision on whether or not to invest time (and perhaps a subscription) to this game.\n\n[Updated: Spelling corrections]"

The game's concept of doing what you want with massive freedom sounds great.

reviewText: Its a dog eat dog world. The game is pretty buggy and laggy but it runs fine for me. The problem is it gives a bad first impression because the main starting city (Tindrem) is just very populated so it lags more than anywhere else. It is a game where you will run into many hard learned lessons but it is extremely fun to progress and get stronger. It is a hard and unforgiving game at the beginning, but give it a few hours and once you start getting up to speed and properly understanding mechanics, you will discover how much content there is and how much fun there is to be had. I played the original client in 2012 and I have to say, the game hasn't come super far in regards to content (Sarducaa is a big one though), but hundreds of bugs have been squashed and Mortal is much more stable and reliable than I remember. I recommend it for anyone who likes open world, sandbox, hardcore-ish, and open playstyle games.

reviewText:
I installed this game two times, created three characters, and have unistalled for the last time.  I wanted to love this game, I really did.  I love sandbox style playing but this was so unbearably painful, I wasted hours just wandering and accomplishing anything.

I installed in initially and found out my computer was not capable of playing with good FPS but I tried.  After dying once, it took my 30 minutes to make it to the resurrection priest due to the video lag.  Once I upgraded my computer, I had great FPS, not that the graphics are that good, but I wanted to love this game so I overlooked it.

I was invited to a guild/clan whatever and was given basic instructions on how to get to their town.  I was killed so many times that I decided to walk for hours as a ghost so that I wouldn't die so much.  I walked in the world for 2 days, real days, about 4 hours each day searching for this town and got so lost, I deleted the character and started over again.

This time I was determined to like this game by not leaving the town I started in and level up going into the graveyard.  This is where the irritation set in.  You need to kill zombies and skeletons and then hurry as fast as possible to collect your loot because people just stand around you waiting and then steal it.  When they are not doing that, they purposely jump in from of you trying to make you hit them so you become wanted and the town guards kill you.  Once you die in the graveyard, good luck walking around finding the closest resurrection priest, there isn't one very close, then you have to go back.

Man I wanted to love this game, but alas I cannot.  Even as I write this, I want to redownload and try again, but I guess I'm too old now to have 15 hours a day to put into gaming.

reviewText:
Don't let this steam playtime fool you, I have played Mortal Online off and on for years.  I have probably hundreds if not thousands of hours on it... After the great game Star Wars Galaxies shut down I had searched for a sandbox game, with a unique crafting system in an open-world sandbox.  I found it here.  Mortal Online is an AMAZING Medieval Hardcore Sandbox MMORPG and will show you that not all mmorpgs are WoW-copies.  Great combat system, the greatest crafting system I have EVER seen.  A beautiful open world filled with endless adventures.  Played in first-person mode, it uses a skill-based melee combat system, block left/right/center, attack left/right/center, or use magic or bows.  If you have the attention span of an adult, you will not find a game better than this anywhere.

Pros: Open World | Best Crafting System Ever | Taming and COUNTLESS other features that will keep you playing for very long periods of time |  Great player economy | Great Pve | Great PvP | Territory control | City/keep building | And so much more.

Cons: Typically bad community.. it's best to play this with friends because many people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s on this game (this is what has ruined it for me in the past). | There used to be alot of bugs in this game but they have made absolutely amazing progress in fixing the vast majority of them, however of course some still remain such as the Trade Broker being stuttery which is quite annoying to me | Steep learning curve, but if you look at sandbox survival games like Rust, alot of people enjoy that type of thing | Free to play model disadvantages free players |

All in all, Mortal Online is an amazing game that is totally free to try.  You have no excuse for not trying it! Give it a try! See if you like it!  I sure do.

reviewText:
Personal Note:

I have been playing this game since 2010 up until now. I have been through countless sieges, been with many guilds and have also explored everything worth exploring (including the new continent). I also swam around the entire continent of Myrland (the first continent) just to see if I had missed something hidden away.

I do not recommend this game at all and although that may seem odd considering I have withered through the countless, yet boring PvE, Building, Sieging activities. But I have reached my limit with this game, it's community and it's company (a title they do not deserve). Corruption, Bugs, Empty Content, Exploits and Cheats.

With fond memories of this game, I can say that it WOULD have been a truly fantastic game, that put all the hardcore wannabe games to shame, but unfortunately rampant corruption, bugs and a community with a majority of muppets have continued to drag this game downhill.


The Actual Review:



Graphics and Preformance:

The game has improved slightly but is still not even close to games in this Decade... There is large amounts of FPS lag, even on modern top-medium gamer computers. Crashing is also a major problem that gets bandaged, but not fixed. All in all... it's not too bad, but it can be frustrating and sometimes just maddening. The terrain is acceptable (on flatlands atleast) with lovely pubic hair-like trees splashed around here and there. The mountains and hills of course... is probably where you'll be doing most of your dying, are crappily made and are basically like ice ramps. However there are some wonderful scenic places like atop Fabernum Mountain, or the Myrland Jungles at night time,  etc...


Gameplay:

Mortal Online Gameplay differs in many ways from your usual MMORPG, there are no real AI quests, no real AI factions, nothing but a few AI towns and a pile  of Player-Made villages and Territory Control Structures (you can think of it like Rust, except taking down walls, houses or keeps takes literally hours of your time unless you have many people).

There are many things  you can do, and most likely, if you want to progress at an acceptable speed, you'd need to subscribe, buy gold/items with r/l money, exploit and dupe, etc. Their are many professions to do, alchemy, smithing, armor crafting, taming, etc... you are limited to 1100 points (normally 100 points per primary skill). Many skills are secondary so you can have as many of them as you want!

Unfortunately, PVP within the game is ruled by whoever can hide a Cheat Engine better, or whoever has the best latency to the server. There is no shield against hackers, and feigned ignorance by the Player-GMs (yes... GM's are either players themselves, or have friends who play the game...). Corruption is a HUGE problem in this game and nothing is ever done except the odd Counselor/GM who will get removed but not banned (when enough evidence is against him.... PLAYER evidence -.-).

New players will probably never be able to compete with the major guilds in this game
date: as all the best resources are held by the largest clans and they all "nutcup" each other. It is likely that those large clans also have what is commonly referred to as "pocket GMs" within the MO Community. Like typical MMORPGs
recommended: the nerds at the top are the ones who buy in-game content with real like money so don't compete if you pockets aint deep!\n\nComing to the end of my rant/review

reviewText: Amazing game, I played many hours before the steam release and it's one of the only MMO's I have found to fit the immersive 1st Person, Fantasy, Sandbox criteria I have so desired. A mind-boggling quantity of things to do anywhere from pickpocketing and taming creatures to crafting a weapon by selecting each material its made of from the core out. Don't even get me started on cooking and alchemy, hundreds upon hundreds of ingredients to choose from with the quantity of each altering the outcome of your recipes....\nWith one massive and persistent game world, the immersion is intense not only from the game world created by the developers but also by the social and economic world created by the players. Kingdoms rise and fall, territorial borders expand or dissapear, and great warriors or mages make their names known with their skill in combat not some invisible calculation played out by the computer after you press a bunch of hotkeys. You must aim both your attack and block, with several other factors such as character speed and weapon type making dramatic changes to combat styles and tactics.\nYes this game does have some bugs, it is unfortunately the price to pay for a pioneer MMO sandbox game with real time virtual world interactions such as hit box based combat for each body part as well as constructable keeps, houses and cities. Mortal is constantly being refined and Starvault is determined to satisfy this game genre.

reviewText:
It's an interesting concept. A game with no rails to guide you. No world-saving/destroying/modifying plot to spur you on to the next set of increasingly harder goals to clear.

An interesting concept that falls flat pretty much right out the gate. The tutorial section is a poorly designed mess. Reading and following the instructions scratches at a surface that promises fascinating depths, but penetrating the UI to find the specific thing you're looking for is an exercise in frustration.

Learning new skills requires your character reading a book... the very first book I got had an 18 hour timer, and the act of standing there, watching that timer tick down improved my skill in 'reading' and after half an hour brought it down to fifteen hours. Whoop-dee-doo.

I'm never one to rail on a game's graphics, for their own sake. But as dated as this game looks, it should at least boast a more stable frame rate. Instead, I had to tone the options down, and get used to the idea that playable" would have to suffice.

Finally
date: wandering the lands on a quest to do whatever thing you wanted to go set out to do might have been enjoyable... if you could move at a speed other than "shamble".\n\nMy experience can be best described as "Poor
recommended: with moderate hope of something better buried beneath the wreckage." a more patient player may derive hours of joy from the experience. I forsee only hours of tedium."

reviewText:
Mortal Online is close to everything I want in a game. You can progress in anyway you want to gain fortune and fame, from fishing, to crafting, cooking or becoming a PVP monster or PVE God for soloing a Ratzar Queen.

You level your character's skills in a classless way that determines how you want to play rather than simply getting stronger through grinding. This allows PVE and PVP to be geared towards skill and grouping with others to achieve success.

This game is first person only but it works to its advantage, to bring a game that's more immersive than any other MMORPG since Ultimate Online.

The community is small but this works to its advantage because everyone is in the same world, on the same server and your actions WILL be remembered by other players. If you start pickpocketing, players will remember your name and try to avoid you in the future. This also means interactions are more personal and political alliances in this game actually make an impact in the way you play, down to what towns you should avoid and who you feel you can trust to talk to.

This game has managed to implement concepts (player-created items only and a balanced player-driven marketplace for example) and take them to a level that other MMORPGs can only dream of achieving. This is impressive since the development team are only 3-4 man strong.

If you're a fan of Ultima Online, Runescape or other hardcore MMORPGs for their full loot-drop and criminal systems then Mortal Online is the king of them at the moment. Only time will tell if other games on the horizon will knock MO off its pedestal, such as Life is Feudal, Gloria Victis or Chronicles of Elyria.

The game isn't without its flaws though. The dev team is small so major improvements take a long time. There are bugs and exploits that you will discover once you really get into the game. Fortunately they're not quite enough to stop me from playing.

My biggest bugbears with the game at the moment are:

* Lag spikes while crossing node lines
* Mobs sitting on node lines being invincible
* Blue text exploiting (Members of another guild that you're warred against can leave their guild and attack you without you knowing they're an enemy because their name text is blue instead of orange).
* Characters or pets getting stuck in the environment. Most of the time the /stuck command will get you out though.
* Most of the GMs are unhelpful. For example, report someone for blue text exploiting and they won't get punished.

reviewText: Blueblocking.  It's the new griefing and this game is full of it.  Don't let everyone full you.  It'll be days, maybe weeks before you see any actual PVP action.  This game is all about Blueblocking, which is when you swing at a pig, skeleton, etc but a player jumps in your way at the last second and you end up hitting them, oops!  My bad bro, but no then you find out they actually did that on purpose because now you've just been labeled a criminal and EVERYONE will instantly gank you and take everything on your body, including your body (to butcher, eat, craft, whatever), which is funny the first few times it happens, but the humor doesn't last.  Usually the person blueblocking you doesn't even need your stuff.  They just want to grief low level players for no good reason (makes them feel big I guess).\n\nAnyway, until the game finds some way to remove the worst form of griefing I've ever seen I'm not playing it and won't recommend anyone else to either.  All you're going to do is end up a blueblocker yourself.  Played for about a week and had 0 PVP action, lots of blueblocking.

reviewText:
I spent many long hours playing this game and I gone through terrible bugs and even terrible gameplay, but Mortal is still amazing to me and offends more than you can imagine.

The PvP in this game is like none others, It offers skill and understanding of what you're using to complete your object. The PvP takes time to be astounding at and able to fent on your own.  The social interaction and population is fun at times, but at other times, the community can be toxic and annoying. The PvE in this game has wide-variety to different animals, or creatures, but lacks fundamental ideas of challenging an experienced opponent. PvE can take time to get use and understand it completely, but once you master PvE it can be a walk in the park.

This game will not hold your hand and spoon feed you gameplay. This game will make you get on your knees and pick the wolf brush you so badly need.

If I had to give you honestly decision whether to play this game, or not. I would recommend to try this game until you completely understand the game mechanics and gain somewhat of foot holding in Mortal Online. Trust me, There is no chance of you just hopping right into the game and being amazing at Mortal Online. This game takes time to understand and I barely gave much information on what to experience when playing Mortal Online.

reviewText:
Genuienly a great, well-done, fun game with almost limitless freedom and customization. It's so frikkin' immersive you'll forget yourself and your real life obligations. You won't eat, and neither will your babes (because you'll be too busy being someone else in this game). Your children will expire before the flowers in their caps, dying or ere they sicken, but you'll have a great time in this virtual world!

Yes, to address some of the complaints about this game, the community CAN BE pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and fond of griefing. But that doesn't diminish the quality of the game itself. It can't be faulted for the fact it's populated largely by ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Much like the real world, the world of Mortal Online is DANGEROUS, and you need to surround yourself with companions to survive. You CAN go it alone, just be prepared for a much more frustrating journey if you do.

Basically: don't expect an easy, stream-lined, mindless MMO experience, and you'll love this game. I personally don't believe it deserves the sub-par rating it's been given on Steam.

reviewText:
I want to like this game and play it.  I really do.  It has semi-retro graphics which I actually like, the progression of skills isn't handed out easily, and it really makes you figure things out (which can be a little annoying at times).  For me the game really captured the feeling of open world exploration as danger is around every single blade of grass and tree however it has been spoiled by the, in my opinion, overly amount of PKing going on.  I know it is a Hardcore PK type game.  I get that entirely and I tried to embrace it.  But the amount of blue blocking and zerg mentality in the game make it hard to believe that this is a truly believeable breathing world.  It's hard enough to time your attacks with the way enemies seem to move through your character and sometimes possess the same space, making it extremely difficult to even get a kill in without having to run and rest.  I witnessed a group of people enter a crypt only to have them get jumped by several undead (which was truly cool to witness in the retro way it is delivered).  Instead of rallying together two fought side by side while the third attempted to kill the other two in an attempt to fully loot them, while the forth ran past me outside.  And it is contagious, even I would jump on a helpless player due to the extreme lifestyle the game provides.  I even bought a second character slot for a crafting type toon to support my warrior.  So your option is to buy skill books and wait several days of real life time to pass (which does pass while logged off as well).  But I want to PLAY the game not log in, click a book, log off and wait.  It's almost like you need to wait a month offline until your toon is done reading an entire library of crap in order to stand a chance.  Guess it's back to waiting for me.



TLDR version:  Awesome game, challenging and fun.  Wish the game had a PvE server for players who wished to explore the game without having to fear of high end players running them down on horseback.  The only real option to level up your skills is to purchase books and log off while your character reads them.  Really takes the skill" out of skilling up. Combat needs improvement.  It's been out 5 years now.  It is what it is."

reviewText: Ultima Online vets will get this game. You don't start with much in the way of guidance and you are pretty much left to figure it out after the (admittedly terrible) starter quest and introduction. Those who can make it past the slow start are rewarded with a much deeper game that really is very solid despite it's many little bugs and quirks.\n\nIf you are looking for a wow clone, this is not it, stop and turn around. If you are looking for a sandbox style mmo with full loot pvp that plays very similar to UO pre Tram (in 3D ofc) then you will likely enjoy your time in Mortal. Not for the impatient! Don't play the starter quest and quit or you'll really miss out on the meat of the game.

reviewText:
The free version is basically a trial.
i am still f2p, but i will be subbing very soon, ive been playing 3 DAYS, and have killed p2p players.
IT IS SKILL BASED, the only advantage p2p has is skill cap is up too 100 as opposed to 60,
attributes are the same for both.
Heavy armor training is not available for f2p, but you can still wear the same armor (you will move slower) only because your skills are capped at 60 (though trainable to 100 still) and you need 100 armor training to learn heavy armor (but not to wear it)

REDS will try to kill you, but if you cant dodge them, its really your fault unless its a full blown zerg (rareish)
I have only died by a red once in three days.... dont keep touching the hot pan and expect it to not burn you..
this game is a pvp game, its open, its everywhere, stop crying about it please.

GEAR HELPS ALOT
ATTRIBUTES HELP ALOT
SKILLS POINTS HELP
BUT ACTUAL SKILL WINS EVERYTIME

if you are similarly geared to a p2p, and you have your skill points at 60, with proper attributes, YOU WILL STAND A CHANCE depending on your actual level of skill irl.
TRUST ME.
Im going p2p JUST SO I CAN CRAFT and because i know that when i get my skills unlocked to 100 (im at cap for f2p), ill be a monster.

THIS GAME IS NOT FOR WEAK MINDS, you will be killed, you will have to think and learn, but it IS worth it. You will be helped, but not handheld and guided through repetitive quests.
You can do whatever you want in this game. Seriously.

Think of it as midevil DayZ or Wasteland mod, you can have better gear, but you can still die to someone. You will eventually lose your ♥♥♥♥.

THERE IS NO MAP, but that adds to the fun and value of knowledge.
THERE ARE NO QUESTS, but that adds to your own adventure and you lose the restrictions of the linear progression type of mmo.

Stick with it, trust noone (at first), and be smart and know what your getting into.
this is the most fun i have had in a game, regardless of graphics or trolls. its fun.
Its risky, and its not a calculator tab target mindless mmo yall seem to be used too.

if you were content with the cookie cutter grindy mmo, go for those and dont spam help chat with your QQ. We dont care. We all have died and lost FAR more than you will ever have gotten in the game, and loved it.
if you want your skill and knowledge to matter, to feel like your actually in a player driven world (its completely player driven and awesome), if you want insane crafting and combat that gives you a rush like no other, this is for you.

DONT PLAY A HARDCORE GAME AND EXPECT IT NOT TO BE HARDCORE

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of mmo's. I've played many ranging from Ultima Online to Wildstar to Darkfall. This game is not for everyone, and it certainly warrants having mixed reviews. However, I love this game! Why? I love open world pvp, exploration and sandbox. There is no map in this game. The tutorial is very brief and no one holds your hand. If I were new to the mmo scene I'd be intimidated by the lack of direction and large scale chaos. There are 8 major cities with guards to protect you, outside of this most every structure in the game is player made. Entire areas have been won by coalitions of guilds working together to war with rival guilds. There are player made maps online with a live feed for recent conflicts and territory/resource disputes. Players can build houses wherever but these houses can be looted and destroyed by other players. When you die, your loot is left to be looted provided you're not in an area protected by guards or your allies. So you pretty much will lose everything on your person but  you can store it safely in the bank. This game is hardcore. Loss of loot, theft murder, no map. There's something called 'blue blocking' where people jump in front of your swing so you're marked as a criminal; you're then murdered and they take your stuff. So watch your surroundings and be smart. The game is first person and free to play up to a level 60/100 cap in skills ranging from taming and breeding animals to mounted combat to jump, etc. The variety of skills reminds me of runescape. I've already subscribed to have access to thieving skills and to move past that level cap on skill, because I love the game. The community is not toxic. The community is harsh and unforgiving, to an extent. Old players aren't in the newbie zones, this game has been around since 2010 so they're off yonder lost to the gossip of us newcomers. The occasional raid of murderers come through to eliminate newbies at the first mob spawns, but experienced whiteknight players step in to police the area. This game functions on your reputation and your worth. If you spend your time stuck grinding in the graveyard and think that's all this game is, you've only scratched the surface. This game is brutal but rewarding. If you like high risk and high reward this game's for you. Expect to be irritated, but be patient, you will have to invest your time. This game is not for everyone. But if you like the idea of a hardcore open world sandbox where some play fair and others don't care and everyone's fighting for what they want or their guild, get involved and learn to play. You'll have to read about where to go and what to do elsewhere, this game does not hold your hand at all. But I love that. There's the thrill of hiding from players hunting you, and carrying torches into a dark dungeon, hoping the zombies don't swarm you when you can't see them coming. Check it out. If you have no experience with mmos, you'll likely be overwhelmed. If you hate pvp, don't even play this game. You will be fighting for you and your group's survival in a world of vicious and ruthless killers. Compassion does exist though. Make friends and keep them. It's dangerous to travel alone.

reviewText:
Final review after 50 hours.

in this review ill talk about the different aspects of the game and the positives and negatives of these aspects. Keep in mind that as a F2P player this is my experience. I cant discuss every aspect but here are some that really got to me and made my impression of the game.

PvP: lets start with PvP since its at the core of the game. If you dont like PvP, dont even bother. you cant avoid it.

+ you can kill anyone and anyone can kill you. Its exciting to murder someone and take all their stuff and then hide so other players dont kill you. There is a criminal system in the game. if you hit somebody you are flagged as a criminal and the guards will kill you. The players are encouraged to kill the criminals for their loot as looting an innocent makes you a criminal. Killing criminals is fun.

i havent experience group fights so i dont know how that works.

- as a F2P player, its GG. P2P murderers come around kill you instantly and there is nothing you can do about it. As a F2P, your skills are capped at 60/100 which is incredibly weak.

- The game claims the combat is skill based. Its not true AT ALL. The game lags so much people hit you from 10 meters away with their back turned. Timing your blocks is almost impossible as the lag makes it so you always block too late.

- Exploitable. Everyone is blueblocking" which is to run in front of somebody as he is swinging his weapon to be hit by accident
date: turning the victim into a criminal. the blueblocker can now freely kill the victim and take all his stuff. This is a really easy way to get gear early on. i found that almost everyone is doing it.\n\n- The rich players are some of the most rotten people ive ever met in-game
recommended: especially subscribers that you find in the beginner areas. These hypocrites will gladly defend victims of blueblocking yet the same people turn around and kill you for no reason. Avoid the geared players like the plague. Leave the beginner town as soon as you can. These ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ruin all the fun.\n\nPvE: the pvp is bad
hoursPlayed:
surely the PvE is better right?... right?

+ You can train your skills by killing pigs.

- The PvE is so bad. So so bad. Monsters will hit you from 10 meters away
voteText:
follow you to the other side of the map and will even swim through a river to get you. You cannot evade attacks. Monsters will always hit you no matter what you do. All you can do is attack and block the best you can. Boring and difficult. No skill involved.

Open World:

+ This game has an epic open world. No loading screen
helpfulPercent: nothing. While dated
votesHelpful: the graphics look really good and you can spend alot of time just admiring the landscape and the environment. Creatures are scattered around the world for you to discover. The world is also filled with player made cities which is really cool since it makes the world feel alive. I didnt get to explore the new desert continent
votesTotal:
but ive heard its cool too.

- i cant really think of anything bad about the game world really other that it has no map. it has that old feel to it like those weird games where you never knew where you were going because you were too young to understand how a compass works. Im kind of mixed on this one.

Crafting:

+ its really cool. I love that everything is player made. The beginner gear can be bought at the merchant but its kind of crap anyways. For those who like the hardcore experience
votesFunny: the crafting system is very complicated. just to make an armor
commentsCount: you need a few materials and its not clear how to obtain them.\n\n+ while getting the materials you need to craft good gear is really hard judging by the amount of campers and killers around
column16: it really gives you a goal
column17:
something to do in the game. You want to go get your epic armor and brag about it. maybe kill a few people you know.

- Good luck getting the good materials on your own. you have to find the materials which are not close to town and come back with it hoping you dont get killed.

General experience:

This game has a great potential. Its actually fun when you meet a bunch of people and go on an adventure. I went with a group to a different town and some guy gave all of us some really cool armor. We rode horses and overall was really fun. But these experiences are limited. you wont always find friends to do stuff. And the items you get
column18: youll lose them to a pker or a random dude will jump in front of your sword.\n\nWhile the idea and the mechanics are really cool
column19: this game is one of the most unpolished mmos ive ever played. The UI is awkward and buggy. The server disconnects you often and you die. People often walk through walls or walk on water. you can hit people offscreen due to lag or weird animations.\n\nI know this is a really small dev team
column20:
but this is no excuse for having a game so buggy and unpolished as this.

Final verdict: TL;DR dont subscribe.

i like this game. it really has alot of potential. I tried my best to have fun and do stuff
column21: but its really had and the F2P limitations and overall gameplay and quality this game offers is bad. Even if i were a subscribed player
column22: the game is a mess and there is nothing to do other than kill F2P noobs.\n\nOverall this game feels like its in Beta. It was released 5 years ago and the state the game is does not warrant a 15$ monthly subscription."

reviewText:
The full PvP aspect gives this game a horror/survival feeling that I dont get from other MMOs with hundreds or thousands of players on the same server. The PvP is aim-based and even tho gear plays its part, a skilled veteran will outplay a group of beginners, not because of superior gear or higher level, but from pure skill.

I love how there are no levels or classes. You choose what skills to learn by actually doing them or by reading books and you can choose between hundreds of skills to build a unique character.

The crafting system is absolutly huge. You can combine almost any weaponhead on any handletype and craft it out of any material you find. Players constantly discover new weapons and armors to counter whatever is the currently most popular gear. You just might find a way to craft a better armor or weapon then anyone else has found yet.

The Full loot aspect can be frustrating if you die transporting valuables, but that means you can also find good loot from killing other players. As a veteran player I have learned a few tricks to stay safe when I want to.

Mortal Online is by far the best MMO Ive ever played and I recommend it to everyone. Just remember that its a hardcore game and you will need to stay on your toes every second of it.

PS, Did I mention it has full nudity?

reviewText:
I am actually enjoying this game but I don't understand why monster/animal animations are so bad, they do not match the hit, feels like it's laggy or bugged, some people told me it's been like that for 4 years+ and it doesn't look like it's going to get fixed.

Don't get me wrong, I love combat system, it requires skill and timing, punishes you for trying to spam attacks or not blocking properly, but honestly when it comes to kill monsters most of them have animations that don't match the hits, you get hit and then the attack animation shows up, or the opposite, you see the animation is coming so you try to block and you get hit right after.

Everything else looks great tho, exploring is amazing, the game actually looks good (do not trust youtube videos, it looks better than that), skill system is amazing, crafting is great.

PS: If you are new to the game (like me) play safe in Tindrem, level some skills, earn some money and read some books, make friends in there, try to join a guild and then leave that city, it is full of griefers and most people quit the game because they don't know where else to go.

reviewText:
Have spent many hours in this game since beta 2009 when i was more naive had fun but then woke up to myself and the fun was gone. The game has had many problems including dupes of items with no punishment, exploits, performance issues, game breaking bugs that crash your client/computer and more.

It still hasn't had a wipe even with the amount of dupes been in the game not to mention the unlimited number of corrupt GM's. For people who don't know GM's in the game are actually just volunteers that play the game which some eventually get spawning powers and are able to give stuff to there friends like gold/items etc.

The company is just far too indie its 2 guys doing stuff for the game so takes ages to get stuff done. To give you an idea they got greenlit on steam 2012 its now 3/4 in 2015 and it finally came out on steam.

How the company runs the game: 1 out of 5 stars
The idea and potential of the game: 4 out of 5 stars
Game play put in practice: 2 out of 5 stars
Player GMs: 0 out of 5 stars (stupidest idea ever)
Cheat detection: 0 out of 5 stars

reviewText:
For final score scroll down
unlimited trial need to sub for competitive playin... what can i say about MO?? well... its a certain type of mmo that caters to those that like to work for their own gear and have the freedom to become a good" or "badguy". there are alot of negative reviews because to go from noob ----> pro or atleast average is a giant leap. the learning curve is steep and unless you seek help from a guild will be a long journey of being ganked/robbed/eaten/zerged and my all favourite blueblocked. i myself am currently a solo player that gets mercyless killed at the drop of a hat from many players but that is to be expected from being solo. Ive met some other solo players that join longstanding guilds to quitting and making a tempory new guild. This game has very intense moment to some very dull moments. atm the population from steam release has dropped to a sweet spot of 300 to 500 and all the problems from server restarts and long queue join times is nonexistant. there are many bugs that need addressing from random character animations (on horse mainly) and npcs being able to walk through walls and shoot you from inside of them.
Pros: hard and gritty
great community(with a couple of griefers)
full loot drop
many variations character classes(build to your playstyle)
playerskilled based
roleplay friendly
can eat own head

Cons:needs some rebalancing
steep learning curve(though i liked it)
old engine
glitches
the random and occasional griefers(when i say griefers i mean priest spawn killers or vets prerying in GY)

i give this game 7/10
its my type of game but many wont/cant appreciate the hard and grittyness of this game.
TLDR; darksouls mmo but with glitches and a economy system

reviewText:
So, let me start by saying this game is not fore everyone. It is a hardcore game with a strong focus on player skill and pvp. Were you good at pvp is WoW? Well, almost none of those skills will transfer over.

This game's is best described as the old ultima online but in 3d (before the felucia tram split). You can be attacked ANYWHERE!!!! In towns you do have guards that will save/avenge you but it is always a risk. There is a thieving system so getting you pockets picked is a real risk. There are tamers, mages, dominators, warriors and any combination thereof. You get to decide what skills you train and what you dont.

Pro's
Very hard gameplay
Very in depth mechanics
visually on par with most games out now,
Does not take massive ammounts of hours to do anything fun,
Excellent combat system

Con's
Bugs. Some of which have been around for a while from what i understand
Very Hard Gameplay (belonged in both because it limits who joins the game)


That about wraps it up. I've been playing for about 1 week and already have 92 hours into it.

Cheers
Jander

reviewText:
Robert getting in your face? Drop that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!

THIS IS A FULL LOOT FULL PVP GAME! There are not many games out there that fit this niche. 99% of all gear you see players wear are the product of rock being mined and refined and crafted by players, yet when you die it ALL drops! This is what makes the game such a thrill.

NO REAL CLASSES! Your skills level based on your own actions! Want to be a melee sword fighter? Hit ♥♥♥♥ with a sword man. Want to also cast some magic? Read a ♥♥♥♥ing book. If you are tired of how your characters skills are, just hit the minus key and train up something else! It's an ever-evolving character!

I have played this game for a few years now (pre-steam release) and it is simply epic. The politics are insane, the battles are adrenaline filled, and the dungeons are gorgeous!

It is FREE to play. Yes your skills are capped at 60 (instead of 100) if you do not subscribe, but I played as a free2play for a few weeks before finally deciding to sub. I currently have 3 subscribed accounts with 4 characters on each. This ♥♥♥♥ gets THAT serious.

reviewText:
Please note this is coming from an extremely biased standpoint of loving games like Shadowbane and Minecraft. I crave the horrible graphic deadly grind games. It's a problem.

That being said! If you are the sort of person who adores the idea of a game where you start out as a tiny squishy weakling who barely knows how to swim or properly eat food, I think you'll dig this. There is zero structure after the tutorial, no quests, no guidelines. Just a boot to the ♥♥♥ and the constant reminder of your mortality (get it? Mortal online? hyuck hyuck).



BULLETPOINTS:
Pros-
◄Super sandboxy
◄Helpful playerbase
◄Expansive explorable world
◄You can tame bunnies
◄YOU CAN TAME BUNNIES

Cons-
◄Graphics feel ~7 years old or so
◄UI is limited in customization
◄Combat feels disjointed and hitboxes are a guessing game
◄There is no in-game map (It's an intentional design, but the admins do not respond with Learn to navigate!"- Instead

Definitely worth the download to check out as F2P! Just keep in mind
recommended: F2P is more of an unlimited "trial" than it is a true F2P model."

reviewText:
Created a character,  completed the tutorial. On a suggestion from a NPC guard right inside the city, I went to the graveyard to kill undead for gold. I killed 3 walkers and accidentally looted a player's body right next to the walker's corpse because I thought it was the walker's corpse. I looted fast because of Full Loot mechanics and thieves everywhere. Became a criminal for having a player's head in my inventory and get immediately cut down by a player in blue steel armor and wings on his back.

11/10 would spend more time installing game then actually playing and dying to a runescape wannabe player again.

Serious post-humor EDIT: After spending 30 minutes trying log into the game and only recieving 'Contacting server. Verifying...'  and then nothing happens, I probably should have given up. After attempting to create a character and getting stuck not being able to click out of reading ancestry bios because I have no way of changing my resolution or windowed;full windowed mode, I should of given up. After spending 10 minutes running from one tutorial quest NPC to the next and then getting stuck on a rock on the ground the size of a small turtle, I should of given up. After spending another 10 minutes running through the city asking for directions to the graveyard and looking for signs to it listening to old-school morrowind-ripoff-esque music and looking at bland morrowind-looking graphics, I should of gave up.

After getting killed in a well known noob area of the game outside of the starting city to toxic, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ veteran players, I gave up.

reviewText:
I have been playing this game since prior to steam release, I have approximately 1000 hours logged in this game.  I will say if you can get past the starting area and join a guild.  This will be one the best gaming experiences of your life.  The game is very hardcore, there are a LOT of people griefing new players.  There is a reason for this though, the idea of the game is that you arent safe anywhere.  You may get killed and you might get griefed but the fact is if you manage to play the game for 30 hours or longer you will be well established enough that you will have multiple sets of gear.

Pros of the game:
-True Sandbox
-Open-World PvP
-Crafting system is very in-depth
-PvP is skill based
-PvE is skill based
-Game is actively being improved by developers

Cons of the game:
-Trolls trolling new players
-Has some bugs and glitches, but none game-breaking
-Game is virtually unplayable solo
-Development team can be a bit slow on releasing patch notes

I hope all of you manage to get past the beginning zone and start enjoying this game.  Join a guild, fight together and this game will be the most enjoyable game you've ever played.

reviewText:
This game is a good way to waste time. You might enjoy playing it for awhile but there's not much to do. Most of the gameplay is horribly designed. A lot of the textures look like they just paid for stock images. The combat is very clunky and attack telegraphing is ridiculously bad. Bugs bugs bugs everywhere, including hair textures that still, after 6 years, haven't been fixed. Movement is so slow that it's more fun to run around when you're dead. I'm not joking, when you're dead it's so much easier to move around that being alive feels like wading through quicksand in comparison. Generally speaking, this game is a chore and it's even worse if you play solo. If you decide to play, I highly suggest you join a guild so you actually have a community to interact with outside of the temporary help chat. This game is very much a sandbox when it comes to the question of 'wtf do I do'. Guilds help a lot with giving you a clear goal and providing a motivation for pvping.

To be fair, the main draw is the pvp. I haven't voluntarily participated in that much yet...by which I mean I've just been randomly murdered a bunch. Oh, by the by, there is no real penalty for murder until you've reached the lvl of a serial killer which to me makes no sense whatsoever, but hey, I'm sure the murderers enjoy it. If you want to seriously get into pvp, I highly recommend a guild. In fact guilds are one of the game's few saving graces, though there are plenty of bugs and other problems going on in that respect too. Outside of pvp however, there's the crafting.

The crafting system is passable and has some interesting aspects to it with how materials affect the appearance and stats of crafted items. However, you have to dedicate a character to crafting for it to really be worth your time. You CAN make a hybrid sure, but, because this game DOES have traditional lvling in the sense that the more you do what you do the higher your stats go, up to a cap, you will be gimped compared to a min/maxing player.

Stats are very important. Do not let people tell you that it's skill based and your stats don't matter. Stat differences determine your health, stamina, and mana as well as your movement speed, attack speed, damage, combat move speed, move speed while using armor, swimming speed, mount speed, etc etc. See a trend? Your skill as a player is limited by what your character is actually capable of. AKA it doesn't matter how good the player is when your character moves like a slug in comparison and does a fraction of the damage.

Ultimately it's your equipment that's most important in determining how much damage you actually do, but you CAN win with skill using crappier gear if your stats are comparible. Blocking/parrying is important but your gear and stats also affect how well you can do those too, so they won't save you against a character with better gear and stats. Damage potential is not nearly as important as movement ability. If your movement speed was determined soley by gear instead of stats maybe combat could be properly balanced, as of right now though, whoever's stats are higher and has better gear is usually going to win over skill. In that respect, this game is very much an RPG. There's nothing wrong with games that put character skill over player skill. The problem is that this game is not presented that way so you go in expecting something very different from what you actually get.

All this talk of stats brings up one of this game's main issues.  MO is guilty of one of the problems F2P games are most criticized for. It is P2W. You could argue that the free to play option is actually just a trial, but that doesn't change that there is a 40% stat difference between a free and subbed player. This game is not listed as a demo on steam, it is listed as a free to play game. Unless that suddenly changes, to say it's just a 'trial' version is a fallacy. It's true that the game is free of the cash shop aspect, techinically. Instead, players receive special items and perks if they donate enough. Sounds a little sketchy right?

TL;DR
Basically, this a fun game to ♥♥♥♥ around in if you like exploring and hardcore rping pvp, but in the long run it's not worth your time. If you join up with a guild you could definitely spend hundreds of hours pvping, rping, and exploring, but it can feel more like a job than fun times with friends. I do not recommend this game for the average gamer. It is for hardcore pvp players only. I don't mean that as a compliment. I mean that only hardcore players will be wiling to put up with all the game's crushing flaws out of desperation to find a game that provides an immersive sandbox rp/pvp environment.

reviewText:
When looking at this game, keep an open mind. ITS NOT LIKE OTHER MMOS. People will kill you, people will grief you, you will get blue blocked (Players step in front of you making your flag to turn grey allowing guards to kill you.) and there will be no consequences. Its your job to learn and adapt to the hardcore environment. Dont just give up!!

The game revolves around completely skill/timing based combat similar to that of Chivalry medieval warfare.

With a flagging system mirroring SAO (Sword Art Online) - Blue Players are lawful and are aloud in towns. Grey players have recently commited a crime and can be killed without consequence. Red players, are your average day Thugs and Murderers who have completely devoted themselfes to ♥♥♥♥ing with your ♥♥♥♥, and ruining your day.

--------THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS LEVELING--------
Skill Trees similar to that of skyrim. You have to train skills up by using them rather then by leveling up. There is a point cap meaning that you have to train your points wisely. This is how mortal earns its money, It requires membership to fully max out a certain perk. For example, if your training a swordskill as Non-mem you can only raise it to effective level 60, A member can raise it fully to 100. There is lots of arguement as to whether or not this is pay to win, but a game has to make money some how, and in my opinion you can still manage as a Non-Mem.

If your okay with these systems, and fine with extremely hardcore mechanics, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND giving this game a decent chance. You may come to find something you truly enjoy.
-Lost

reviewText:
Played Mortal in 2011, it sucked. It's alot better now and the noob killing that most negative reviewers are subjected to is really their own fault..This is a game about being in a unforgiving world with little to no safety nets. The only protection you do get in Mortal are high level guards inside of towns. Otherwise, you're on your own.

Very brief guide to new players on how to get started and not get PvP'd ---

#1. Join a guild ASAP. http://www.mortalonline.com/forums/forums/guild-recruitment.145/
#2. Pick flowers - Cactus are worth alot of cash to vendors.
#3. Did you join a guild yet?
#4. Red players (murderers) are ♥♥♥♥♥. If you see one, avoid the area for 30 minutes. Don't go back and die again. Picking resources off of the ground (flowers, cacti, bor) in low population areas = $$PROFIT$$
#5. JOIN A GUILD.

Good luck..It's a cruel, cruel world and the grind is real, but this game is very fulfilling when you begin to make progress.

reviewText:
I've been searching for a MMORPG like this for few years. Until I stumble over this great game on STEAM. Alright, if you're hardcore player looking for some ultra-realistic MMO, Mortal Online is your best choice! A lot of people complain that this game is harsh, community is awful and etc. But let me tell you the truth, the community in this game is helpful, kind and always willing to lend their hands to the starter. I have to admit that the beginning town is harsh, and the community is quite toxific. But after you join a guild and get out from there, you can truly experience all the potential this game offers.

Some of the features:
This game use a mount & blade / chivalry style combat system. Apart from that, you lost all your items on dead. This game is fixed to a FPS view, to maximise the immersion. There's no leveling system, all your gameplay revolve around your skills, and all skills become better as you use them, or read a book (remember to read reading when you start playing, lol). There's a overall skill level cap for each character, which is 1100. The purpose of this cap is to limit down the things can be done by one person and promote player interactions. In real life, you can never be a master smith and master swordman at the same time, if u focus on something, you wont be good at the other things, but if u learn everything, you wont be very good in everything. This game is not mission based, and dont expect the dev. to tell you anything, you have to discover them yourself. The only things they tell you is through the tutorial basic. There's a lot of player made village and town in this game, some with such beautiful scenario that you will thought it's a pre-made town.

Moreover, the history, the society, the politics" are written by the players themselves! This is a true open world game

reviewText:
ive played this game for a month or two. and i have died countless times, lost items ive worked hard for and bought with blood(because i butcher) and tears(of the animals i killed to butcher their corpses) and at first i was actually really angry. its not fair that these vets are picking on new people who barely know the functions and mechanics of the game. but then i kept playing, i presevered and i didnt want these aholes to win by forcing me out for their own lil amusement. and you know what. i love playing now. i found myself a nice town at magna astu to make my base of operations. i go out and explore with things i made myself, saves the loss when i die. and yno there are so much more things i can find out.

YES. there are going to be players who will kill you, take your stuff and kill your mount. there are going to be things you wont know at first and lose out on. BUT thats not all there is to this game. its not all about pvp, even if many people feels that way. i personally love crafting. i still havent gone into the dungeons but i want to, there are special monsters around that are uncommon, boss monsters even. i was actually suprised to know that there are actually equipment that you can only get from drops (previously thought everything was only crafted)

you dont get everything handed to you in the beginnning. there are ALOT to learn. but go into the forums and search abit. there are guides for new players, for crafting, for building certain builds. there are people that just feels like sharing what they learned that day. there are alot of nice people playing as well. many people who have faced the problems with red and grew to be able to fight them. they know some tricks and they have resources to help. find some guilds to join, there are a quite a bit of players willing to help. because it will benefit them if there are more players too. more people to play with, adventure with. slay monsters and hunt bosses with.

the hardest thing i found in this game is the fact that it really is up to you to learn, grown and develop your character and play style. you cant stay ignorant in this game, that is what kills you.

im no vet, but im up to help new players. because its a nice dream of mine to lead a hunting group around, fight off some reds, go dungeoneering. bring a nice fresh air to this game that has staled because people keeps getting scared off.

try it. got nothing to lose, its not like you HAVE to suscribe. im f2p player and im enjoying myself. xP

Great Game, would recomend to anyone and everyone.

The game does have a very tought start, especialy if you're new, but if you can get past the first month, you should know enough to be able to work your way up. Your best option is to join a guild right away. The GY farming is 100 useless, it's just something to do, but you need to do a little reseach, and figure out better ways to make you gold.

The game does take time to learn the mechanics, and the whole system from crafting, extracting, butchering, etc... Almost all the information you need is a simple google search, so if you find yourself stuck, just do a little reading, and then do your own testing, because not everything is 100% accurate, but it will give you an idea and head start.

My first month, I lost everything I farmed in 30 seconds. This is when I learned, I need to find a guild, and I need to learn better ways to make gold. Get past this part of the game, and the game with be very enjoyable...

What I dislike, is how NPC Guards work... thank for the lictor SV

reviewText:
This game is absolutely terrible. Even for RPG fans like me it's just pretty badly made.

My gameplay experience in a nutshell:

- waited over 2 hours to create a character.
- played a bit.
- accidently hit another player while I tried to kill a pig.
- got killed by guards.
- twice.
- respawned where somewhere, couldn't return to the tutorial area.
- deleted my character.
- 4 times in a row.
- created a new one.
- completed his tutorial and that's it.
- game throws you into open water and says swim"
- you have no idea where to go.
- you have no idea how to do.
- the fighting feels like I am an old fart with hurting bones.
- "sprinting" feels like a slow stroll.
- I died out of nothing.
- I'm done.

The game works not like it should do...

All that worked was the uninstall button.

Overall gameplay: 2/10
Graphics: 7/10
UI: 3/10
HUD: 3/10
Newbie friendly: -1/10

Final verdict: 3/10 Do not play this game. Even as an RPG fan. Not even because it's F2P... Just  don't DO IT"

reviewText:
iv been playing Mortal Online since beta and have been an active player in the community since than and till now havent quiet the game. Since i found Mortal Online i havent realy played any other Online games, maybe tryed them out for a bit but nothing held my attention as long as this game.

What is Mortal Online?
its an mmorpg full loot true real open world sandbox game. you can do whatever you want. you have no classes you make your own class with the skill points that are provided.
think of it as Ultima Online but in 3d (Henrik the CEO is acctualy a real fan of Ultima Online and you will see alot of similarities towrds Ultima Online)

you are nowhere safe even in town with guards its possible if your smart to kill you, or yes steal stuff from people what they have in there inventory. you got free house placement in the world. no instances just one huge world!!!!

this is not your typical theme-world game where you point click bash your keyboard and hit nrs to win. your skill truly matters, you need to block, and acctualy hit the person with your weapon.

so kinda like skyrim if ultima online doesnt ring a bell.

i want to point out they are a indie company, so it does have bugs but trust me since iv played it alot of people who might have quiet came back because there is truly no other game out there like this.

another thing is please do not say its pay to win, this is a game where you have to have an subscription, but it gives you the option to TRY THE GAME OUT FOR FREE FOR AN UNLIMITED TIME!!!!!

you are a bit restricted when it comes to skilling your toon so instead getting 100 in a skill you can only get 60, while once your pay to play it will go up to 100. if you decide to take a break its no problem, once you resub all your skills go back to 100.

if you want a true skill game where you can do whatever you want, acctualy aim and fight like in skyrim and dont mind full loot (whatever you have on you when the person kills you its theres) than this is the game for you.

i also want to point out to people who might think ehhhhhhhhh what?!!! i will loose everything i have one me?!!!!?!? nooooooo, never!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

stuff to get in this game is not as hard like in other games for example World of Warcraft where you have to grind hrs just to get 1 certain armor part. once you have your gold its no big deal if you loose stuff, just remember take with you only what you need.

its really a game you havent seen before try it!!!!
