reviewText:
Your experience may vary, but you MUST try itTL;DR;
I have been playing Mortal Online for over a week before it came out on Steam. The short version: If you're into MMOs, this game is definitely something you should give a go, if only for its uniqueness. It plays like an Elder Scrolls game with a feudal Eve Online twist. As objectively as I can, I'd rate this game 85/100.

The Game-play
This is where Mortal Online shines.  The best Genre Tag to describe the game would be Hardcore MMO RPG. You can be killed anywhere by anyone. You'll drop everything you have on you when you die. And the best part? There is almost no hand holding for the entire experience. Mortal forces players to learn everything by trial and error. And I'm not only talking about game mechanics like how to fight or gather resources. I'm talking about things like crafting recipes and interaction with the game world. For one thing, there are no crafting recipes like you would expect in other games. There is no giant icon that tells you what item you will get for what resources. Not only can you craft the same thing with different materials, but you can use different amounts of those materials. And both of those things affect the final item stats and looks. That is to say of course, if your character even has the ability to tell the quality of your craft goods... Which brings me to my next point.

Character Progression
There are no set classes or character levels in Mortal Online. The experience of your character is defined by the skills that he has learned. There are several hundred skills in the game. Skills are generally graded anywhere from 0 to 100 and they're also classified as primary and secondary. Every character has a maximum of 1100 skill points to use for primary skills. Secondary skills don't cost any points. Now the skills themselves influence everything you do. Your ability to run, to fight, to block and jump. Your ability to comprehend how good some armor or sword is. What the affects of a potion are. What nutrition a food item has. How much you can carry while swimming and still not drown. What animal you can manage to keep under control. The list goes on. There are literally HUNDREDS of skills. Your character even has a skill for breathing. No joke. And you can train all of them! If you can find a combination of skills that works for you, congratulations, you have your own class".

World and Game Content
Mortal Online has been out and available for several years. Its only had one expansion in that time. And yet its had a consistent and solid player-base the whole time. Do you want to know why? I think one of the main reasons is because nobody has "finished" it. That's right. In the years that the game has been out
date: not one person has gone through all the content the game has to offer. That's a very refreshing thing to hear
recommended: considering that other MMO that shall not be named has to keep releasing expansions every year just so its players have things to do. I can guess what you're thinking. "Oh
hoursPlayed: its probably a horrible grind-fest". No. Almost any one skill can be leveled to max in a day or so. The secret is that Mortal Online relies heavily on player knowledge and skill. Your own skill
voteText: not your characters. Did you ever read or watch a show about some magician or alchemist
helpfulPercent: that spends years locked away somewhere researching potent new potions that the world has never seen? Well
votesHelpful: now is your chance to do exactly that. And please please
votesTotal: if you figure out how to get mana potions that don't kill the mages
votesFunny:
I'll pay you everything I own for the recipe.

The negatives
Outdated payment method. The game runs on an "forever trial" with a possible monthly subscription fee. F2P is only good to check the game out. The limitation is that skills are capped at 60 instead of 100. This is a huge limitation. You hit the ceiling after about a single day
commentsCount: and this prevents you from playing the game competitively. Otherwise
column16: you are completely free to see and do anything you want. Skills caps don't stop you from doing anything
column17: it's just that other players will be better at it.\nBugs. The game is too complex for its own good. The sheer amount of intricacy makes it near impossible to not have issues pop up here and there. Fear not
column18: the bug report forums are quite active and the developers are
column19: in general
column20: responding to player issues.\nSteep learning curve. This is an enjoyable part of the game for me personally. There is something nostalgic about the game telling you very little and you having to figure stuff out by trial and error. However
column21: the "modern player" might not see it this way
column22: and thus the lack of things like minimaps and directional arrows on the screen will be seen as a negative for people.\nSlightly dated graphics. Once again
column23: this is only from the perspective of your average current day player. Many people don't realize that when you can literally look around for miles
column24: you can't expect to have photo realism. Having said that
column25: the game doesn't look ugly. Its retro. Embrace it.\nNot to finish on a low note
column26: I'd just like to make it perfectly clear for everyone: given the chance
column27: Mortal Online will raise your bar for all MMO's you play after it. It's completely unsurprising that there are people who haven't played anything else since. And I'm really upset with myself that I didn't find out about it sooner."

reviewText:
As much as I enjoy MMORPGs, this one has just thrown me away hard, I have barely any time played but don't let that push you away from my Review.

While I was in game I talked to some players familiar with the game:

Benefits of F2P

- None, it's just a trial, steer clear of this game.

Benefits of P2P

- Well as usual, you unlock everything. No skill caps, house creation, etc,.

It doesn't seem like much, but for a first person sandbox mmo, to declare itself as free2play, it should have all features unlocked, with some features limited in what they do.

Example - House creation should be unlocked for EVERYONE. HOWEVER, you can't be allowed to put up banners or paintings, or make fireplaces. AND you should also have a limit on how big your house can be and the materials used in it.

As it stands right now, they want you to pay to try out a feature, which you really shouldn't have to do if its saying free2play, if something big(and for a sandbox mmo, housing is a BIG feature cause it adds immersion.) Its literally saying hey
date: we know you want this and we said its free
hoursPlayed: pay up."\n\n4/10"

reviewText:
I've played non stop for 2 & 1/2 years and played briefly through beta and the expansions and I can say this game has come a long way. While there still are bugs and some issues, the game is playable to a point where you can easily look past the bugs and minor things that occur due to the enjoyment that comes with playing this game.

This MMO is unique. It has a steep learning curve, 1st person only view, full loot, no safe/PvP zones, large world to explore, Great indepth alchemy/cooking and crafting system.  As a new player you will die a lot, this is a hardcore game where you can die anywhere, anyplace, so just soldier through the hardships, skill up your character and immerse yourself in this game, once you get past the rough beginning you'll start to see what this game has to offer from different land scapes to large scale PvP/sieges, to small group PvP to indepth cooking and crafting and different types of PvE content.

While the NPC guided quest end at the tutorial, there are secrets to explore in the world and little missions that are like quest, so PvE content is there to explore and have fun with. You might have to kill some giant bug and collect its eyes for a rare book or kill a boss mob for a key to unlock a chest etc This game is not like your normal theme park" mmo which will hold your hand almost through your whole experience

reviewText:
Bonjour à tous,

Alors que dire:

LES POUR

-Libertés de création de personnage, pas de pré-set de choix de carrière, total liberté pour les métiers.
-Graphique plutot plaisant, (bien que ne vaut pas du tout les AAA game actuel, le jeu à plus de 5 ans)
-Le monde est assez grand, et totalement ouvert à tous, on peux rentrer dans les maison dormir, manger etc...
-Vue à la premiere personne.
-Les combats.

- NEW EDITE:

-Beaucoup de skills comptez une bonne centaine, ou pas loin en tout cas.
-Le crafting ( inégnieurie ou consturction) très bien fait, et une vrai liberté, beaucoup d'armes armure et autre potions etc...sont encore inconnus même des anciens...et ce qui est decouvert reste secret et non dévoilé par les guild ou autres joueurs.
-Le fait de devoir gérer sa nourriture, son repos, ce qui fonctionne sur un ensemble de reserve de points de vie, de mana, et d'endurance.
-Une vrai économie de jeu, au vus du nombre très bas de vendeur PNJ, qui d'ailleurs ne vendent que les nessecaire de base armures, ingrédient, livres etc...Cela poussent les joueurs a crafter et à vendre le produit sur la bourse d'echange...Nottament pour les armes.( pas de vendeur d'armes dans le jeu)
-Constuire sa Maison ( vous aurez besoin d'une guild pour ca et de temps poru collecter le nessecaire)



LES CONTRES:

-Bon déjà, je pense que les devs confondent, libertés totale et anarchie ( ou plutôt Chaos)..
-Il n'y pas de liberté dans ce jeu, au sens, que c'est un jeu PvP et seulement PVP, dans un Open World...
-Essayer de looté quelques ingrédients est juste impossible, à cause du paquet de RPK ( Random Player Killer,   comprenez qu'ils tuent tout ceux qu'ils croissent ).

-La monté des skills ne se fait quasi que par livres, chose plutôt sensé,, sauf quand, on voit qu'il faut 10 jours pour lire un livres..10 jour de temps réelle et pas celui du jeu..Chronophage game ??
( Cela change et réduit le temps necessaire de lecture, avec la compétence inteligence, et le skill ' reading " (lecture)
date: il continus aussi d'apprendre quand vous êtes déconnecté du jeu)\n\n-Les équipements
recommended: armures et ingrédients du jeu sont tous identiques ou du moins de base...rien de bien folichon et faut dire qu'il y a pas grand choix...( Je parle pour les vendeur PNJ de cuir d'ingrédient

reviewText:
Game is good if it is your kind of thing.

Full Loot
Non-Instanced world
Real time combat
Skill based progression
First person only
...etc,

Rough around the edges, ie, a lot of small annoying bugs and some bigger noticeable ones, but much of it can be avoided or ignored if you learn to. Game is not for the light hearted.

reviewText:
Not worth playing as F2P, you will not be pvp viable. Quickly becoming nothing more than a target for others to slaughter and no way to really fight back. Thus, making it very difficult to  learn all of the aspects of the game.

Not worth the Sub. At least not until the Dev's work out the server issues from the influx of new players due to steam release. In the short time that I have tried this game, I have spent more time trying to log in, than I have been able to play. There is no way I will pay for that.

Otherwise, it looks to be a great game. A game that would take an unGodly amount of time to learn, and advance a character through. Huge skill tree with innumerable options.

I could see countless hours being spent in this game creating characters, deleting characters, trying new approaches each time.
However, In my humble opinion. I cant recommend this game without doing it with Sub. I cannot recommend a sub, until they have a better log in rate.

reviewText:
I will start this review by first stating that I am a new player (since the steam release), and I must say....
I AM ABSOLUTELY LOVING IT!!!
This game is amazing in so many ways... It's basically SAO / Morrowind / Rust. It's the game I've always wanted.

Everyone who is being deterred by the negative reviews, please take some things into consideration before making your decision at face value.

1 - have a look at the hours played by most of the negative reviewers. This is a hardcore sandbox game, can you really have any right to post a negative review after only playing a few hours? They've probably seen 0.001% of the game...

2 - To the negative reviewers who have played it a bit more, please notice that they are complaining primarily about the freedom allowed to the toxic" players. Let's think about that for a moment. They decided to play a open world sandbox mmo... and they want less freedom... Logic?

3 - You control your experience in this game
recommended: let's talk about number 3 for a moment.\n\nMy MO experience has been a rollercoaster of emotions. From developing PTSD brought about by the presence of possibly murderous surrounding players
hoursPlayed: to being given a full kit of armour by a kindly knight
voteText: this game is always smacking me in the face with surprises.\n\nI once partied with a fellow in the crypts underneath the Tindrum graveyard
helpfulPercent: and spent the entire time wondering if he was going to turn around and stab me in the back. Lo and behold
votesHelpful: he actually saved me numerous times
votesTotal: and protected my loot when I had a clumsy death. I felt like I made a real connection with this dude. In a sea of murderers and vagabonds
votesFunny: I found a buddy to help weather the storm. This wasn't some random idiot who I had been forced to party with for some dumb dungeon quest for some dumb storyline that I don't give a crap about
commentsCount: this was a mateship bonded in a need to survive
column16: and forged with our skills as players. There are plenty of other great experiences I've had
column17:
and the good ones far outweigh the bad.


TLDR:
YOU CONTROL YOUR EXPERIENCE. This game is your opportunity to play the way you've always wanted. The best part is
column18: the game doesn't just give it to you... You must earn your right to thrive
column19: and damn
column20: it's satisfying when you do."

reviewText:
This is a game that im unsure about, While it can  be fun selling shields/weapons that you make to other players and leveling a wide variety of skills, it also can be extremely annoying to play.

An example of this is my first Life (first death) so to speak.

Keep in mind that when you die you lose everything so you MUST put your items into the bank.

So after some research into builds i decided to play as a mage as i thought it would be fun casting spells in first person.
So i comnplete the tutorial and purchase my books and go to the graveyard to make some money and get some experience playing as a mage.

So i am healing all of these different people fighting the undead and i also cast a few spells to hit the walkers, but then a player decides to run infront of my spell on purpose and due to that everyone is able to kill me without consequence and loot all my stuff (which is called blue blocking) which happens quite a lot in the graveyard.

I should also mention that mages need reagents to cast their spells and you get a few of them from the starter pack you get from the captain. So after i died i had no money, no reagents and all i could do was scavenge from the undead corpses.

One thing that made the best experience of the game so far was that i joined a group of people traveling to a city (one of them was streaming the journey) and then i got mauled by a dog and then the dog mauled everyone else.

So yes it can be a lot of fun but it can be one of the most frustrating and annoying games that you might ever play, but with a game like this its all a part of the experience and it is free after all so i would reccomend getting a few of your friends to download it with you and start playing as a group. :D Because it can be one of the best games you will play and will be a memorable experience


Pros:

+Freeform sandbox gameplay - The game is what you make of it

+Wide variety of skills to train (Up to 60 for free to play players)

+Player driven Economy

+Ability to craft a unique weapon out of so many different materials

+Requires dedication to learning how to play the game

Cons:

-May be confusing for new players at first

-can be extremely frustrating due to griefers

-Alot of planning must go into your character builds to get the most out of your character (you only get one as a free to play)

Important Note - The game is an unlimited trial rather than a true free to play experience.

reviewText:
First of all, if you never played a sandbox MMO you might not like this game, its an entire different genre from the most common themepark MMO you see everyday, for those who love a good sandbox this is the game for you.

This game has incredible deep crafting systems, creating items is not just following a recipe, you can experiment with different materials and designs, cooking and alchemy can use up to 14 ingredients at once

There are several player towns, and if you manage to form a big guild you can as well build your own

Enconomy and politics are controlled by players

The world is merciless and so are the players, if you like high risk high reward situations you will find plenty here

reviewText:
This game sadly is unplayable.

Technical Aspects!

First you have to create a account / the buttons are not responsive so it can be that the game itself doesnt notice that you pressed the button. A browser pops up and you type it in manually.
After youve done that, you log in your account. The serverstructure is unknown,you join a server after you created a character.
As i mentioned before, the buttons are not responsive. I created the character and pressed the button to finalize, but it didnt let me.
Going back,i found my character suddenly standing there.
After 3 attempts of login-errors, the game started. It loaded very slowly,took about 5 minutes.
The game wasnt taking any graphic-settings that i set in the settings of it before starting the game.
Ingame the framerate dropped after a few seconds to 1 picture in 5 seconds. I put everything on the lowest settings, still nothing (and this game is old unreal engine)
I exited the settings, and suddenly my mousepointer of the menu was still in the game. I was disabled to look left and right.

Gameplay Aspects!

While creating the looks of your character (a few hairs, a few colours, nothing adjustable, all preset)
you can also select your race beforehand. (they all have the same player model, one is a little thiner, one got a beard, one has some more skin details, one got a scar over his eye).
4 Races total.
Then you pick what your grandfather and grandmother were, to get some additional stats. Theres huge lore about it, but not really straight up what it does in the game.

Nice for a f2p. but only as a fun-mod i suppose. Some people create that for other games in their freetime.
Not worth the effort.

reviewText:
Pros:

Has some cool idea that I had really wanted to check out.
Guild run territories
housing
a lot of freedome
varied skills

Cons:

Gameplay feels sluggish and dated
Total pay-to-win
Skills cannot be increased past 60 on a free account
sub based
Many areas are over-camped by higher level players killing off new characters (with what I read in chat)
Older Graphics

Overall, I wouldn't recommend the game until the sub-based premium is dropped and they adopt a GW2 style payment method.

Increase in area size for the tutorial zones would help alleviate the horde of players swinging like freaks at the same 2 pigs.

Finally the graphics could be overlooked but the game still feels sluggish.

So it has potential but the starter zone was full of people killing the same 2-3 pigs that actually spawned. After mentioning in help chat" that i wasn't sure i was keen on the pay-to-win model
date: i get lagged out. Check the forums to find i've been IP banned. So that was neat.\n"

Installed the game files. Ran the program and selected Create Account".

Was sent to the Game's official website.  Set up my account. Tried to login several times. Kept ending up in a Queue telling me to wait 2 Min (Which was in reality 10-15 min each time)

*LOOKS* like a cool game (I was a huge fan of Ultima Online back in the day and I've heard it compared to that several times)

While waiting in the queue looked over the site and account info and realized that this "Free to Play" game is actually a "Pay to Win" game.  Extortion in gaming doesn't sit well with me so it no longer resides on my HDD.

If you're going to do F2P do it RIGHT.  Look at games like STO (Star Trek Online) or PWI (Perfect World International) Where it is actually FREE to play. and not "PAY to win"  but rather "PATIENCE to Win" -- you don't NEED to cash shop in those games to get uber gear. You just need to WORK for it (Remember doing that?  "WORKING" for your rewards? -- Yeah... that's the way to fo F2P IMO)"

reviewText:
This game sadly is unplayable.

Technical Aspects!

First you have to create a account / the buttons are not responsive so it can be that the game itself doesnt notice that you pressed the button. A browser pops up and you type it in manually.
After youve done that, you log in your account. The serverstructure is unknown,you join a server after you created a character.
As i mentioned before, the buttons are not responsive. I created the character and pressed the button to finalize, but it didnt let me.
Going back,i found my character suddenly standing there.
After 3 attempts of login-errors, the game started. It loaded very slowly,took about 5 minutes.
The game wasnt taking any graphic-settings that i set in the settings of it before starting the game.
Ingame the framerate dropped after a few seconds to 1 picture in 5 seconds. I put everything on the lowest settings, still nothing (and this game is old unreal engine)
I exited the settings, and suddenly my mousepointer of the menu was still in the game. I was disabled to look left and right.

Gameplay Aspects!

While creating the looks of your character (a few hairs, a few colours, nothing adjustable, all preset)
you can also select your race beforehand. (they all have the same player model, one is a little thiner, one got a beard, one has some more skin details, one got a scar over his eye).
4 Races total.
Then you pick what your grandfather and grandmother were, to get some additional stats. Theres huge lore about it, but not really straight up what it does in the game.

Nice for a f2p. but only as a fun-mod i suppose. Some people create that for other games in their freetime.
Not worth the effort.

reviewText:
HELL NO!

Now hear me out. I gave this game a good hour and a half. I like the concept of the game. That being said, that is all I like about the game. Where to begin.

GM's, you would think they would be helpful, but they are not. I asked for help on how to craft a robe (because the tut is total garbage) After the 4th time of asking in help I was banned from help chat, for asking for help (GM said I was spamming) But I only re asked the question because no one would answer in help, they were all too busy fighting over weather or not the game was worth 15 dollars a month (Its not)......

Gameplay, well, once you've tried to run around for 10 minutes, you will quickly recognize something is amiss.. You feel like you are running through a field of molases weighed down by 100lbs... FPS is good, but it feels like you are lagging when you really arent.

Community, toxic to say the least. And thats putting it nicely. And GM's do try to stem the tide of complaints and fights, but they arent effective in the least.

Basically, this is a game from 2010, that they are asking 15 dollars a month for. Yea you can play for free, but lets be realistic here, the perks you get form subbing make this very close to a p2w game if not completely.

Moral of the story, stay away from this game, and its greedy devs, who obviously only released this to steam in an attempt to milk some money out of the community.

reviewText:
First of all, if you never played a sandbox MMO you might not like this game, its an entire different genre from the most common themepark MMO you see everyday, for those who love a good sandbox this is the game for you.

This game has incredible deep crafting systems, creating items is not just following a recipe, you can experiment with different materials and designs, cooking and alchemy can use up to 14 ingredients at once

There are several player towns, and if you manage to form a big guild you can as well build your own

Enconomy and politics are controlled by players

The world is merciless and so are the players, if you like high risk high reward situations you will find plenty here

reviewText:
So I downloaded the game, made a character, picked a starting place, and pressed play. It won't get past that first loading screen after I press play. Anyone know what to do?

***EDIT***
Thanks to FarmerJoe I was able to get the game to work! If anyone else is having this issue, try this:
go to your Steam library, right click on 'Mortal Online' on your list, click on 'Properties', click 'VERIFY INTEGRITY OF GAME CACHE...' under the 'LOCAL FILES' tab, and then try to launch the game again. This worked for me. It said one thing was missing and it got fixed. Thank you FarmerJoe!!!

reviewText:
Edited Review:

Alright. I reinstalled the game after the dev modified the account creation.
Your information is only needed if you're getting the subscription outside of Steam.

Now, onto the game itself.

First loading it up, and the game...looked rather poor, despite my World and Character settings being as high as they go. There is a horrible head-bob that I did not see a way to turn off.

I did the tutorial (unlike 50% of the people in help chat), and found it lacking. It told you the BARE essentials to playing the game. Walk, kill stuff, craft basic thing, tame little animal. After the tutorial, you are left on your own devices to wander around wherever you started. And when I say wander, I mean wander aimlessly, lost, as there is no map system, and very few landmarks to use as orientation.

Skills require you to learn them from tutors, but good luck actually finding them. They have no indicators showing you can learn from them.

Now, the combat. While trying to kill the pigs in the tutorial, I felt rather motion sick. The camera swings wildly when you attack. It didn't help that I was experiencing mouse and input lag (I would press a key, and about 1/2 second later the game accepts the input.)

The community, at least in the help chat, are either people screwing around, or people who didn't do the tutorial.

Also, if you don't want to die, don't jump off ledges, don't kill things with blue names...and after one hour of play, avoid all players. The game is focused around PvP, so strong players can murder anyone they so feel like, and when they do, you lose ALL of your items and hard work.

Overall, it feels like this game was made very long ago, and so I must say no, I don't recommend it.

reviewText:
Not for the lighthearted, worth the download, more than worth the experience.

Devs should probably lean towards a cosmetic microtransactions model, but the FTP model is currently more like a free-to-try model.

I have only had good and interesting experiences with this game.

If the dev team had the level of ambition to match their passion and integrity, this game would be on epic proportions.

This game is fun! I been getting into sandboxes recently and for a Free game, this is by far one of the better ones.
You literally need other players to help you out in this game. You CAN solo, but to get that Bow that is better, you need someone to make you it. For better armor? Have someone make it. Yeah, you can by them at Brokers and some low level stuff. But you are best getting it from players.

I am no Veteran to this game however. I only played it for a few days, and so far, my only concern with it is...

My FPS, no matter what, is ALWAYS low. It does not start off that way, it just randomly happens over time. Like 20-40 minutes into the game. I will go from running smoothly to can even move because I get .58-5.00 FPS Its ALWAYS in red.
After the first two times that happen, it never goes about 24 now. The game became unplayable. I figured my computer is not good enough for it. BUT that is my only bad thing.

reviewText: I can definetly reccomend this game to anyone who can pay the subscription. Mortal Online is first and formost a fantasy life-sim, and it's ♥♥♥♥ing awsome. But, without subscription you don't get access to the life-sim aspects of the game, that to my mind could make the game one of the best ever. There is no story, and no real quests, you can find a few odd jobs to do for NPC's but the game both pushes the idea of, and makes it extremely easy to join/make a guild, and use them to make money, and really just Role-play your life as a character in this world. Currently, I'm playing a mercenary who's traveling with a group of players who, Instead of going the combat rout, decided to become a caravan of traveling merchants, and it's ♥♥♥♥ing cool. If you can pay the subscription, you can build a guild, a home, and even a town if you feel the need to, and it's an increadable adventure.

reviewText:
So I downloaded the game, made a character, picked a starting place, and pressed play. It won't get past that first loading screen after I press play. Anyone know what to do?

***EDIT***
Thanks to FarmerJoe I was able to get the game to work! If anyone else is having this issue, try this:
go to your Steam library, right click on 'Mortal Online' on your list, click on 'Properties', click 'VERIFY INTEGRITY OF GAME CACHE...' under the 'LOCAL FILES' tab, and then try to launch the game again. This worked for me. It said one thing was missing and it got fixed. Thank you FarmerJoe!!!

reviewText:
I've been playing mortal for quite a good few years, and i can honestly say there is no game like it out there.  Yes its a bit buggy here and there, but with a devolpment team of 5 people what can you expect?

I remember when i first started playing, and i convinced a friend to come try it with me. We were riding along a bridge, near bakti over the top of the jungle, and my friends donkey decided it didnt like him. I remember laughing hyserically as i watched his now flailing body fly over the rail of the bridge, off the cliff into the deep dark jungle.
Then began the quest to recover his body, we got him rezzed and got his donkey back, and ventured off.

I felt honest to god fear, navigating my way through the jungle in the depths of night, torch in hand and sword in other. and the excitment we got finding his bag. We picked it all up and celebrated...right before we were jumped on by a Terror Bird...Lost it all.

There is NO game out there you can expirence that sort of situatuion in. This game dosent hold your hand, and newer gamers dont like that. If your expecting quests, an easy leveling expirence, being told where to go and what to do...this game is not for you. If you want a hardcore sanbox expirence, with unlimited crafting, and so many options it isnt funny...And can look past a few bugs...this game is for you

reviewText:
Just started this when it came to Steam (no idea it existed until then, despite searching for an MMO with this kind of combat system for a long time). It's good. It's damn good. It's a bit like Wurm Online (the game Notch made before Minecraft for those unaware) but has active combat and not a block/grid-based environment.

First person only can be a little bit of an issue for some people especially when it comes to trying to hit with the proper part of your weapon - if you have a hard time with this use swords and you will be fine, axes and spears can be more difficult to strike with their heads. If anyone's ever played Mount & Blade in first person before, you can expect about the same experience here.

However the Steam launch has been a little bit much for their server and during peak hours there have been several crashes and periods of downtime. Give the devs time to sort these out and come back to this gem. Be prepared to subscribe after a couple days trying it out though because the free to play restrictions are geared more toward being a demo than anything else. Nothing wrong with that in my books.

reviewText:
A critical review by experienced player

WHY I WOULD RECOMMEND MORTAL ONLINE AND TO WHOM?

Simply, because it is the only MMO on the market that effectively delivers next features without making compromises: true sandbox, realtime FPV The Elder Scrolls style combat, non-instanced open-world, full-loot, complex crafting system, taming and pet owning, true player driven economy and finally a true free to place guild asset building like castles, own army of NPCs, walls etc. On the other side, Mortal Online has many downsides, it lacks a lot of polishing and more bugfixing, which I cower later in text. I would recommend this game exclusively to players who seek before mentioned features and are ready to master its mechanics with minimum of handholding. Its gameplay shall make much greater challenge than in any other MMO and accepting great chance of being killed by other players or mobs and losing some of the belongings in the process, but with much greater reward at the end when one masters the play. I note that to be competitive one must be ready to buy a subscription.

WHY KEEP ON PLAYING MORTAL ONLINE?

Despite all the flaws and issues, all the sandbox features creates vast choice for overall fun gameplay. One can choose to participate in PvP where combat system is truly skillbased and fun most of the time. During group fights, teamwork and personal skill plays a keyrole, outweighting gear quality, unllike in other MMOs. On the other side, personally I enjoy being a crafter, since crafting system gives great variety of item types to be crafted and competing with other crafters in selling weapons to players is fun personal challenge. I could not find any other MMO that offers so many crafting and trading possibilities. Other activities like refining materials, alchemy, taming and trading the vast choice of items is fun to do since player can devise different strategies to get rich out of it. Finally, to explore huge open non-instanced seamless game open world brings its own kind of excitement and immersive experience unlike any MMO that I played, since there are no loading screens or artificial limitations. Game features various environment types like forests, planes, mountains, deserts, jungles etc. Across the world goodies are distributed in form of locked chests and free to loot urns/crates.

GENERAL PLAYING EXPERIENCE

Player can choose to start playing through Tutorial which will make introduction to basic game mechanics like basic combat, taming creatures and crafting armor. When finished, player can choose a starting item kit for desired class archetype. Character does not have classes, instead player just levels skills where the total limitation is 1100 for primary skills which can be redistributed any time freely. For mid-game, Mortal Online has no quests, but the main goal is to advance your personal and character skills, make your own material wealth (gain best items, build a house etc.) and participate in community (in guild or solo).

Pickpocketing other players is possible, but there is a way to counter it easily. Game forces first person view, which creates strong sense of immersion. Player can try to attack anyone anywhere, but most of the NPC towns have NPC guards that can kill any criminal really fast, but a strong group of players can kill these guards. To regulate criminal activity, there is a flagging system. Outside of towns any player can attack any other player, especially if there are no guards to help. When a player dies, all the stuff that one currently carries is dropped on a ground, being lootable by anyone, friends, foes or by returning to own corps. Still, all the valuable stuff can be banked for free in NPC or Guild towns for 100% safe keeping.

Player can engage in PvP and PvE. Combat system is realtime where player has to aim a swing or an arrow to hit other player with realtime blocking also. This system is a true aim based realtime system without autotargeting, same as in The Elderscroolls serial. Practically, players personal skill really matters and often happens that unleveled skilled player can defeat fully leveled players that lacks PvP skills. Still, combat system is not without flaws where network lag can lead to undesired unfair outcomes, but overall the system works well. As for PvE, there are dozens of dungeons to explore which all are uninstanced. World AI still could get some improvement, so PvE is one of the worst aspects of Mortal Online. On the ground level, many challenging mobs exist, but dungeons are more rewarding and challenging.

Crafting and trading is one of Mortal's strongest points, where players can craft almost all the items in Mortal's world, all except skillbooks and mount equipment. On the other side, 90% of available viable weapons and armor are player made. Variety of possible versions of item type to craft is vast, but in practice a few are viable, a few but enough for a rich market. Besides direct player to player trade, all the items and resources can be sold through the trade broker NPC which serves as a stock market, only locally with buyout and buyorder sections. To get required resources for crafting players can mine and refine materials to get metals or other minerals. To get animal materials, there is a butchery skill (one of most boring trade in Mortal), to get potions there is alchemy and to get food there is cooking skill. To get pets and mounts, there is taming skill, but animals can also be bred at NPCs to get better offspring of already tamed animals.

Finally, building territory structure is one of most impressive features of Mortal. A single player can build their own various type of houses in predefined spots. But guilds can build other structures wherever they like. They can build many types of structures, like keeps, barracks, banks, market stands, mines, taverns, libraries... and walls to protect themselves. Overall, guilds can create their own fully functional town wherever the like in the world.


DOWNSIDES

Mortal Online features serious issue experienced from the start of playing. UI is overall a bit clunky and design is lagging behind modern MMO titles. Handling core game mechanics like extracting and crafting can be clunky and quite time consuming to work with, with some minor irritating bugs like items are not placed into slots, or item stacks won't split as expected. Game overall lacks ingame guidance, so the learning curve for new players is just too steep. Due to thievery feature and free to hit combat, starting experience can be just too harsh for new players, leading to many griefing attempts. Further, trade broker user interface features huge technical lag which adds to frustration (screen freezes when loading item entries). Pet and mob AI is not good enough to avoid really strange behaviour during PvE (mobs hit and shoot through walls. Even when traversing the world with pets carrying mined materials following, they could just disappear with valuables due to a bug. Crossing server areas on the world (nodelines), can lead to unfair situation during combats due to a lag or just a bug. Considering crafitng, overall mechanics are not designed to be fluent and lead to many time consuming actions e.g. to butcher a full stack of carcass it takes 45 seconds of just standing at the butcher table. Similar is for extracting rocks, refining etc. Weapon and Armor Crafting UI is also impractical. List of these small but frustrating issues goes on. At last, there is no mid-game and even end-game content that can drive a player to keep playing. There are no ingame challenges to beat, besides personal challenge of getting overall better ingame.

CONCLUSION

Unique and truly functional vast sandbox featuers of Mortal Online that are unique on market barely outweight the vast issues. For a player seeking a true open-world sandbox MMO, Mortal Online is more than good enough to enjoy. At least until a closely similar MMO title appears.

reviewText:
Microsoft Email and Server Load and Verification System 2015

I'm a Libertarian, so don't get me started on the fact that I bought a game on Steam and now I have to create an account with my phone number and address on it, and they are required. You don't need that. This is 2015. The glory of Steam is to buy a game and play it, not jump through hoops (and scary ones at that). These guys can't even get their email or server systems working, you mean to tell me I don't have to worry about a hack when they want all my personal information?

Took 12 hours to get verified to play their game via email. To their credit, they finally fixed it, however, today it took an hour to get on the server and once I finally created a character, it kicked me and said it would be another 15 minutes.

I will update my review once I can actually play the game, but right now the review is based on technical issues because you CAN'T play the game.

I understand a metric @*%@$ ton of people are playing right now, but if the servers weren't ready for Stream or that kind of load, it shouldn't have been released yet. And I can say that, because I actually DO work in the gaming industry on shipped titles.

Thus far, this has been my experience:

1. Can't get email verified
2. Verified 12 hours later
3. Can't log in for an hour
4. Finally am told server will be up in 15 minutes
5. 17 minutes later server still doesn't want to let people on
6. Finally get on, create a character
7. Server crashes
8. Get back on get a quest
9. Turn in Quest
10. Server crashes
11. Down for another 15 (I mean 30) minutes

I promise the review will be better once I can play, but for the last day, I can't.

reviewText:
I've played this game for years prior to Steam Release, and it's honestly one of the deepest MMOs I've ever played. Every system in-game, from the crafting, extraction, combat, cooking, alchemy, taming, etc etc is incredibly fleshed out, with TONS of room for experimentation along the way.

All the best gear and items are player-crafted, resulting in a player-run economy. The Crafting is incredibly dynamic, with countless options. The world is harsh and unforgiving, where you always need to watch your back, and any other player coming across you could be your doom...

No other game has scratched the itch that Mortal does, and I'm glad to see it finally release on Steam.

The free-trial is never ending, so if you'd like to get a taste of the game, download and try it! Just be aware that as a trial-account, you won't be competetive in PVP or crafting against people with Full-accounts. You can try almost everything, though, so there is that. People will whine that's Pay2Win, but it's far from it. It's just a classic Sub-based MMO, with a free trial that DOESN'T end after a week or two, it goes forever.

I definitely recommend trying it out, it's a very unique game, and the dev team deserves all the attention they can get! :D

reviewText:
Have tried for three days to get this game to do something besides splash screen.

No luck.

Edit: I did evantually get the game to load. A little tip for anybody who tries to play this game. The first thing you should do when this game loads is turn off the sound. You spend the first hour or so listening screaming pigs. You're supposed to collect up some skins or something, I dont know, I never could get it to work.

To be honest, after reading the description, getting me to like this game was going to be an uphill battle anyway. I've never understood the movement MMO's have made away from classes and races. Its all skill trees now, so the world is always full of healer-knights. The game only has four races... light-skinned humans with or without pointy ears & dark-skinned humans with or without pointy ears. Theres a couple of paragraphs about each one, but they all looked the same to me. The game attempts to make up for this by letting you cover your toon in tattoos. bleh.

The game does give you a ton of options about the background of your tattooed healer-knight though. You can choose which countries your grandparents came from & this somehow affects your stats in ways that will probably be hugely important later on. The free account only includes one character slot though, so as soon as you figure out which stats are important you'll be deleting your character & starting a new one.

The descriptions for this game go on & on about how important crafting is... indeed the tutorial zone seems to offer little else except an explanation of their crafting system... which makes it all the more puzzling when the in-game tips remind you of how important it is to buy a -campfire- from the local NPC vendor before you go off into the wilderness.

Maybe its a great game once you get into it... i got tired of chasing pigs & uninstalled it.

reviewText:
The only thing easy in this game is dying.

I've been playing Mortal for almost a month now, and I have to say, I'm hooked. Full loot open world HARDCORE game. Not for the feint of heart, or the easily frustrated. So far I've died to random mobs and lost all my stuff, been ganked several times and lost all my stuff, had my mount killed and lost all my stuff, and I attacked someone by accident and got owned by the guards and lost all my stuff. The only thing that's easy in this game is dying, and that's what makes it so much fun to me.  It's like that ex-girlfriend who treats you like crap, sleeps with your friends, and disappears for days, but she's always a blast to be with when she's there.

For those wanting to give it a try, I challenge you to play it for a few hours. Once you get your running skills up, and learn to ride, and get passed the gankers in the graveyards, the game is huge open world with zero safe spots. You can die at any time anywhere and it's EXCITING. Specialization is the key. Join a guild that's helpful to new players, there are vets that like helping new players out. Sure there are douchenozzles in every game, but it really feels to me like there's less of them in Mortal Online than other hardcore full loot pvp games I've played. For every one of the former there are 10 vets who will take time out to help you if you ask.

The free to play aspect of the game makes it really easy for new players to decide what to spend their skill points on with hardly any limiting factors other then effictively capping the skills at 60. Your points still go up to the 100 cap, but need to be unlocked with a subscription plan.

The combat is feels similar to Mount & Blade to me, but with a little less reliance on being mounted all the time. The creatures are plentiful, and better still, very dangerous if you don't know what you're doing. Plenty of adventures abound, and exploring is massive fun.

I reccommend this game fully.

reviewText: Mortal Online is unlike any other MMORPG out there. It is a truly hardcore game akin to the glory days of Ultima Online. It is the only game I have found that makes me feel the way UO did so long ago. There are real consequences to your actions in game and, while this may be seen as a negative by some, I feel it is the only thing that makes an MMO worth playing. The world of Nave is constantly changing as politics and large scale server conflicts radically alter the game world around you. Your allegiances and your behavior truly matter in this game and the people you play with will not forget.\n\nIf you are the kind of player who enjoys a challenge and can withstand a little punishment, Mortal Online is the game for you. It has a steep learning curve at first and can be a little discouraging when you lose your hard-earned posessions, but it is a truly rewarding experience once you figure out what you're doing. I highly recommend this game!

reviewText:
Pros:
Player combat is solid.
Character customization is reasonable.
Fun to play.
Criminal or law-abiding citizen, you can play however you desire.
Full nudity.

Cons:
No clothes, no cosmetics, no roleplay.
Armor is the only type of clothes you will ever wear.

Conclusion:
The gameplay is combat-oriented, with all crafting and trading catering to said combat.
I am a person who enjoys dressing up my characters in classy outfits when entering the inner city.
I do not fault the game for having a single focus on combat, but I would have loved to see some nice dresses, suits, or other form of clothing to wear.

If you are like me and want a bit of extra depth and roleplay opportunity, this game is not for you.

reviewText:
Okay, I was going to wait until I put in 100 hours to judge this game, thus I have put in only 36 hours in five days. This is not a traditional MMO. If you want quest bubbles and some hermit telling you to gather 100 carrots so you can feed a donkey, and then expect to do this a thousand more times, in a thousand different ways until you level to 60, please don't download this game. Mortal Online is not for children nor is it for the faint of heart. This game feels like an RPG with a devoted community. If you loved Morrowind: The Elder Scrolls, then you will remember what a game like that feels like. If you want epic challenge, free romaing adventure, gore, crafting, hunting, taming, PVP, cooking, combat mastery and uniqueness in character; and might I mention some of the deepest lore ever written, then you must try this game. The lore in MO is on the level of the Elder Scrolls; in fact I wish ESO did their game sandbox style like this; if they did maybe people would have stayed.

The game is older so the graphics are not in today's standard, yet the world is beautifully crafted. The combat system works, it is intriguing and while it is challenging it is also fun. Even riding a mount takes skill, so you can't just hop on a horse or donkey and go; you need to learn how to ride, make sure you are not too fat or you will fall on your face in front of everyone. The economy in this system is unique in a sense, that even though you can see everything in the realm at the broker, you can only buy stuff in the city you are in, so it makes things challenging: if you want that armor or weapon you need to travel to the desert lands to retrieve it, from that particular broker, if you can survive the bandit players.

I think open world PVP in 1rst person, is the most feared, yet realistc experience in fantasy gaming.

Many of us got spoiled with 3rd person and I was one of them. At first, I was not sure I wanted to play a game in 1rst person, but as I got into it, I found myself 36 hours in. Then there are those who are afraid of getting killed and losing everything. I will say this, fear is good sometimes, it keeps you on the edge. Once you get killed and lose everything you will be smarter, wiser and learn to only carry the things you really need. And if you need to gather more things, keep a good relationship in the local cities so you can visit your bank; and always have back up resources so you can be prepared for the monster/creatures, theives and red players who have nothing better to do but make your life miserable.  All we need now is more Roleplayers to stop fearing PVP and come to this world. The opportunity to do what you want, go where you please and build a house, village or city, anywhere is well worth the risk. Or you can play ESO and waste your life in a tavern. I rather be rping with friends who want that edge, knowing that they can die in this dangerous world, but gaining strength, will, intelligence, dexterity, constitution and valor; to defend ourselves and the weak. We need more good players in this game.

WE need more Roleplayers, who are up to facing this challenge.

Why don't you join us!

For help or guild information join this community

http://www.mortalonline.com/forums/

For guides see this wiki

http://www.mortaldata.com/wiki/index.php?title=Main_Page

For a map which you can use in game at any time by pressing Tab+Shift see this link

http://www.mortalonlinemap.info/

As always, Characters Welcomed. ~Serverus

reviewText:
So, far, it has been an absolute blast and a refreshing change of pace from our typical MMO. The only issue is that new players must realized this is an ANYTHING GOES sever. Unless there is hacking involved, pretty much everything is fair game.

Which means you can make a living however you want. Whether its farming NPCs, being a bandit, soldier, baker, blacksmith, tamer, and just about anything you can think of. Even a thief or a mugger. Which, for me, is simply perfect.

I also love the lack of 'classes' and 'levels'. It feels dynamic and realistic in how your skills work. Even in when creating your character, your age is a factor in what your starting stats are.

If you are tired of all the WoW clones out there and ready to try something new, even if it is hardcore, then simply give this game a try. It is free after all ;P

reviewText:
OVERALL, I'd say give the game a try. It's free so ♥♥♥♥ it. I was unfortunate enought to try on a day that the 1 server they have was ♥♥♥♥. Then my friend unfortunately ran into every bug you can experience in the first 5 minutes of the game. Hopefully it was just for us.

*Queue Time Kinda Fixed, Skip This Part & Read The 2nd Attempt*

Installed and registered.

Game started running and I'll admit, it was beautiful from the second it launched.

Logging in required me to wait a full 15 minutes, which I assumed was a queue of players. A little annoying but when I enter a game, I'm on for a solid streak. 15 minutes is nothing compared to the grinding session I'm about to begin.

I begin creating my character. While the customization isn't very extensive, it still offers a few unique mechanics that you won't find anywhere else.

While struggling to find a worthy name for my champion, the game suddenly sends me back to the Log In screen, informing me that I've lost connection. I check my internet and find nothing wrong. I had a stream running at the same time which was not interrupting, reassuring me that the error was not on my end.

I log back in.

15 minute Queue.

I'm a bit frusturated at this point.

This time I fly through the character creation. I no longer care about the toon because I just want to play the game after this unproductive 45 minute session.

I enter the the tutorial.

The game is running great. My movement feels smooth. A little different but smooth. I run through the first couple tasks and I'm about to make my first set of armor when I see a notification in chat that the server will be resetting. This is instantly followed by the complaints of other players.

Server goes down. I lose connection.

15 minute queue.

I have now spent 45 minutes of my 1st hour ingame WAITING to play a tutorial.

Game looks great. But somehow as someone who loves to grind hours away with stupid ingame tasks, I've lost patience.



*UPDATE*

Watched my friend play. He logged in after a 13 minute queue and experienced no server issues. He then experienced a few glitches I did not.

The tutorial mission stalled on him. When you're supposed to butcher the animal parts for its leather/hide, you drag the parts over to the butcher skill. He did this and received nothing but Work Bench is not available" or something along those lines. Don't quote me on that.

I knew this wasn't supposed to happen because I personally had passed this part of the tutorial before being disconnected.

Before he could log out and endure another queue just to complete the first step of the tutorial
date: he found that he was rooted to the ground. Unable to move
hoursPlayed:
or rest. We sat there laughing about it until he lost his "fledgling" status. At this point another player approached him and started attacking him.

I watched as he calmly exited and uninstalled the game.


MORAL OF THE STORY?

Gave the game a second try
voteText: and the queue time was a bit shorter... But then the game glitched out.\n\n4/10 still can't play through the tutorial without having to relog whether it be because of glitches or server restarts."

reviewText:
Well, I've given it a try, and decided that this is not the game for me.

While I don't normally play PvP games, I do occassionally like to raise my blood pressure a little by playing some.  Was fully prepared to give this a good strong effort, and accepted that I'd get killed quite a bit.   However, what I've come to discover, is that this game seems geared more towards the griefer than the PvPer.  In my 9 hours of play, not once was I killed by a player, but I was guard killed Many Many times by little 'traps' left behind by players, things that use game mechanics or deception to allow players to get other players (expecially newer players who don't KNOW all the little mechanics) killed without penalty to themselves.

While this might be the game for some, the learning curve and ease with which a player can be tricked into dying and losing all their gear, simply puts this game outside of my interest.

reviewText: OK I put in a good 5+ hours, killed 10 pigs made armor went to graveyard got murdered went to graveyard got murdered rinse and repeat for hours, The veteran players dont seem to want new players and are showing it. So I left the starter town in search of greener pasture. got murdered. walk for 20mins find nothing get murdered, walk for 20 more mins get murdered. Huge game no map. Try to learn the game mechanics which are difficult but enjoyable from what i did manage to accomplish, but try to figure out how to play and u get veteran players killing u or one of their alts jumping between you and your target making u a free kill. I cannot give a full review of the game because i am not able to experience the full game.  In simple terms a game is supposed to be fun, and until you learn a game you cannot really play. Above that it is the players who make any game fun or ruin a game and from my minimal experience the core base of players are hateful, spiteful and toxic to the extreme. The developers of this game obviously want new players which equates to new money(business is businees). On the other hand the old players have made it blatantly obvious they will do anything they can to put people off the game. The only way i would recommend this game is if there was a new server which would be more inviting to new players, yes old players would have a knowledge edge but not the ability to ruin the experience everyone else. Sadly a big thumbs downs not to the game but to the community, The community makes or breaks a game, this game is shattered.

reviewText:
EDIT: After playing for a longer period of time, I can no longer reccomend this game.
The monetisation on this game is far too steep, and the game becomes essentially unplayable without subscribing, AND buying an additional character slot.

You do NOT get an additional slot when you subscribe.
You have to pay more to do so.

To play the game effectively, virtually every class requires resources in the form of reagents and materials, usually metals.

There is a cap on your OVERALL skill distribution, so you can be a good miner, or a good fighter, but NOT BOTH. This means that, to play effectively, you need a seperate character to gather resources, then a seperate character to use those resources.

Effectively, this is a demo, because it's 100% impossible to engage in PvP properly in this game without having those additional sources of resources.

Additionally, to play a mage, you need a constant source of metals, so mages spells just WILL NOT CAST without a consistent source of metals.

All this wouldn't be so bad if they charged a reasonable price for things like slots and sub time, but it's 15EUR for a single month!

Long story short, the game is not only inferior and more grindy than most MMOs, but also considerably more expensive to play.

Don't waste your time, it took hours for the veil to be lifted and for it to be made clear the time and money you need to invest in this game to function.



(OLD REVIEW)
This game does not have a learning curve.
This game does not have a learning cliff.
This game has a learning mobius strip.

It will punish, and tease, and grind you to the bone, but if you invest the time and effort to explore and learn, even for a small period, you'll find a game with depth beyond depth. Think Skyrim meets Dwarf Fortress.

Sadly, this has hurt it's review score, but I honestly think that the learning curve is the only real reason for negative reviews, as on the whole this game has great production values and quite frankly, an awesome development team. Having worked with Unreal Engine, I have some inkling of the effort they've gone to to make this work.

If you think you've got the patience and control, I beg you to give this a go. It's as close to Sword Art Online as we're ever going to get.

reviewText:
This game shows the best parts of people and of course the worst. Through the freedoms that are given you almost have a reflection of the world we see today.

Yes this game is hard, but once you get the hang of it and you know the way of the land you will have an amazing time. This world is so big and the sights to see almost grab you like you are truly in the game.

You ride your horse through the wild and the sun shines through the trees, you almsot have the feeling you are sitting on that horse yourself.

Yes, you will lose your things but the more you play the better you get at keeping them.



Some advice:
-Leave the main cities,  if you die leave again.
-Plan your charecter
-Be nice to people, through this you meet many simular people
-Get the riding skill and buy a mount
-Join a guild
-Roam in a team if you can
-Find the mortal online map
-Stop an attack with Ctrl (you will know why soon)
-Get to know which guilds have what agenda
-Make use of the buy orders on the broker this will make farming a lot easier.
-If you think you going to die just fight and let them know it.
-Ask people where to go and what to do

reviewText:
Played this game about 6 hours, this game had a good potential.
The first problem is this game is not a real free2play but more like a mmo with subscription with a trial edition which end when you reach the 60 level skillcap (just like WoW with the max level 20 but easier in MO).
Second thing, the level design of the world is very cheap, buildings are like big cube even at max graphical settings.
Third thing, informations are hard to reach, for example, the servers were unaccessible yesterday night and there was nowhere to check their status.
Here come the worst part of the game, the griefers. Before I explain what happened, I have to say how the criminal system works, if someone attacks another player, he will be targeted as a criminal, if a guard is near the area, the guard will kill the criminal. Other players will be able to attack the criminal without being flaged as criminal. Of course some people will abuse of this system.
While I was killing some skeletons at the 'safest' capital to buy the last part of my armor set from the auction house (which were sold by players), a random player put himself between me and the skeleton (which was dealing a lot of damages). So to not be targeted as a criminal, I had to aim to nothing which was successful. Funny thing is, npc are not attacking with skillshot like players but simply deal damage when in range to its target. So while this griefer was standing between me and the skeleton, the skeleton was continuing to attack me. Of course as expected, I tried to kill fast enough the skeleton to don't have to deal with the griefer, but I touched the other player when he was beside the skeleton and the attack touched the player when I wasn't even seeing him. To be short, I was then killed by the player. Ironny here you come, when I checked the auction house after, my items which I bought from the same auction house were in store.

The main counter-argument is yeah but it's a hardcore pvp mmo

reviewText:
11/11/2015
Love this game and I would give this a thumbs up if it weren't for the pay model.
Max skill lvl for skills is 100 unless you pay the monthly.(Roughly 12$ a month, weird price because it's in euros.)
But if you cancel your subscription you go back down to 60!!  So you have to perpetually pay just to play the game you already paid for last month.  These kinds of pay models goes against my gamer code of ethics.  It's a scammy way to run your business, you don't really get to keep what you pay for.  But if you don't mind supporting dev's who keep supporting these pay models, then by all means perpetuate the problem. There is one other thing that made me wary of this game is that the experienced players will literally tell you not to talk about bans, or the banning of your friend or really anything to do with banning, because if you do you will get banned yourself.  Just thought it was really weird and got the feeling the dev's have mistreated players.  But it really is a great game and I was really enjoying it but after finding out the pay model I decided against it, due to principle.

I do know  I am in this for a month(since i paid a month, thank goodness only a month) and if things do not drastically change in that month then starvault can be assured that I will not be paying to play a game that I cannot login.

reviewText:
The cons of this game are mainly superficial.
-buggy
-Gm's somewhat useless/unhelpful
-graphics are a little dated
-Slightly p2w due to character slots
-fights are generally a numbers game
-joining a guild gives an advantage

The pros of this game are all gameplay related
-Meaningful Evil alignment, taking peoples gear and money
-Meaningful Good alignment, access to the market place, strength in numbers
-6-7 viable pvp classes
-guild support
-Keep building and empire building
-politics
-wars, and siege weapons
-Interesting magic system
-easy to farm and fast leveling
-macros and dual clienting allowed for 1337 Skillz

reviewText: This game is awful, things like no maps and forced first person perspective. I really, really wanted to get into it and I even had gone into it with a group of friends. The combat system seems dull and the graphics really aren't very good. There's no guides I couldn't even figure out the basics of building up a character, it seems like there's just random skills that are randomly leveled up and you have a maximum number of skills so things like being good at armorcrafting reduce your combat effectiveness. The last time someone tried something like this was SWG, but SWG was way, way, way more intuitive about the costs and what benefits of various playstyles. Maybe it's just too open? Maybe I've been spoonfed by other games since forever and only like the idea of an open world MMO? But either way this was an awful experience and if I had paid money for it I'd want it back.

reviewText:
Mortal online is not a game for everyone, It hard to learn. There is nothing to do if you have no imagination, But if you have imagination and can set your own goals it will be very fun to play, My occupation is a tamer, I choose to tame donkeys to horses. Allkinds of horses. My occupations takes alot of time traveling in the lands , While my side occupation is pretty okey. I kill walking deads for a living meanwhile waiting to get sold my horses / donkeys.

There is so much to do with so much time to be spent. Build your houses , team up with friends and go in dungeons with no loading screens. Build castles and raise an army? Go merchanting and transport gods from city to city and risk getting killed on the way to the city. In the lands of Mortal Online , There is plenty of criminals. You can get killed anywhere in the game , So stay guarded.
voteText: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
i played this game for 2 years before i got it on steam

this game is one of the most accurate first person combat games i have ever found, combat can be extremely difficult against another player, it is based on skill above all else, your survivability is increased due to armour and weapons but it wont make you powerful if you suck. thank god. there seems to be an unlimited amount of things to do from fishing to bounty hunting other players, you can make an empire without ever lifting a blade or you can stand atop a heap of corpses with your battleaxe in hand and faithful donkey by your side.

if you die you lose all the stuff you are holding, also clans can be destroyed and you are never safe, like it should be.
this is one of the harder games so if you arent a little girl you should love it.

be aware of guild spies

every skill you use in the world needs to be advanced, at first you can hardly even walk, jump, run or swim, if you make a character that uses axes, you wont be able to kill another player with a sword unless you have trained with one. also the direction of your swing is important, as well as hitting armour, sheilds, weapon hilts or even other weapons. for e.g. if you hit a piece of armour that protrudes from someones shoulder you are hitting their armour and will do massivley reduced damage, it is very accurate.

all in all an extremely enjoyable first person combat game with indepth clans, trading, crafting, hitboxes and armourments

reviewText:
If you like an empty husk of a game world with broken mechanics and god-awful combat, this is the game for you. The state you see the game in now is the same way it was in 2010 when I first gave this mess a try. The devs ofcourse are the same as ever, giving excuses instead of trying fix issues with the game.

If you do decide to give this one a shot, the free version is a time-killer and a good one at that. But to pay a subscription for the game? Not from me atleast. For that to happen the devs really need to start acting like devs.
You don´t really have to look far to see what I´m talking about. Check out Tindrem for instance, the plaza looks okay-ish but get to the rich area and you will see floating staircases, staircases without any stairs, buildings with doors facing into the wall, huge seams in the ground, etc. What a sorry state it is in.

If someone tells you it gets better outside the starter cities, that is because it gets emptier. Gameplay feature right there.

reviewText: It's a nice idea but poorly implemented. reviewText: Don't let my 0.2 hours fool you. I've had this game for years before it got its steam release... that was supposed to happen years ago. That's this game in a nutshell. This is the worst game with the worst community on any MMO. Yeah it is for hardcore players, meaning you have to be a scum lord IRL and in game. Save yourself the time and effort to commit to this game. Let me give you a long story short... There isn't anything community related in game, EVER.  The game itself is ran by egotistical veteran players with hankerings to ruin the game for new players and ruin the game as a whole (yet they think its just part of the game). The devs also do their own part in ruining the game by never promoting community events, get togethers, or boss events.. This is the epitome of a great game gone all the wrong ways. Let me blow your mind though, THE DEVELOPERS FIRED THE COMMUNITY MOD BECAUSE HE WAS HAVING FUN WITH ALL THE OTHERS HAVING FUN; He wasn't taking his job serious enough." ... and that was the last thread of hope this game had. Don't forget PvP will never be fair
recommended: the beginner zone is the only place where you'll see players. Everywhere else is a barren wasteland of nothing and they'll never focus on player experience. Final thoughts: This game has potential to be the greatest mmofps sandbox ever
hoursPlayed: but sadly it will never be because the community and devs have united to ruin it."

reviewText: I will say this right away, to enjoy this game you need to be part of a guild, at least when you start out. The game does not hold you hand for anything and just troughts you right into it. Howerver ones you get past all of the beginning dilemma and the bugs you see how cool this game actually is. I find my self constantly coming back to it just because of all the cool consepst that it has. this is the only game where I find my self think whether I should take a shortcut trought a alley or not as a murder could be there in the shadows waiting to kill you, things like this and other stuff like the sense of discovery that you get when you find something in some remote part of the map really gives a unique experince. This game really haves a Huge amount of depth to it that you get to see ones you get pass the beginning. But like I said before to get past the beginning you need to find a good guild , to if nothing else , at least show you the ropes, however dont look for a small guild with 3 people .look for something in the forums that has it self stable in the game already.\nIf you trying starting this game out by yourself with no help I promise you quit in less than 3 days just because the game can get really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t when you dont know what to do. People that you dont know can get really toxic and a good amount of the time will go out of their way to screw you,server can be super ♥♥♥♥♥♥ some times and problems have arise with corrupted support system, thought that has decrese a bit. game is full of bugs that you learn to just circumbent or sometimes even love, thought I know this is not excuse as the game has being out for around 6 years. but ones you see past this problems you find a really unique game full of cool things to do just because it gives you so much freedom , you want to build a house in a cool looking place? do it, you want to wall off a section of the map as your back yard? do it, (be ready for consecuenses) you want to go up to people in the wilderness and offer then the choice to give you their stuff or die? do it, you want to be a thief and steal stuff from players inventories? do it, you want to explore the wilderness and dungeons for cool weapons? do it, you want to scout the land for rare magics? you soon be able to do it.\nThings like this and more really make this game something of a gem for me, a flawed gem but a gem non the less. I really do recommend people to give this game a try, and If you do REMENBER TO LOOK FOR  A STABLE GUILD RIGHT AWAY other wise you WILL NOT enjoy this game. a good tip for this would be to look at the map if the guild has a keep they probably know a thing or two and once you ask to join then they must likely will help you

reviewText: My favorite game of all time. Definitely not for the casual softcore player. I've been playing for the past three years probably over 1000 hours played. For someone who finds the most enjoyment out of sandbox full-loot games with skill based PvP this game takes the cake by far. I am yet to find a game that I have ever been able to dump as much time into as Mortal Online. If you don't like full loot pvp and don't have the patience for some minor bugs (small development team with a ton of heart and dedication) then you may not like this game. This game definitely has its niche which is why it is still around today. There has always been a core group of players who love and support this game including me.

reviewText:
I love this game, super hardcore, completly sandbox, hell there is not even any quests!

This game is very pretty, even on awful settings it looks good.

The game itself is hardcore, full loot, part of the community is rude, etc. This may turn people away but you hardcore fellows out there will love this!

Sandbox, you wont even know the meaning of the word after this game, literaly you can do what you want when you want. You can tame stuff, kill stuff make stuff. And all that awsomeness. REMEMBER you lose everything you die, so dont get crazy


There are rude people who will kill you just for the fun of it. But hey there are bound to be there.
Edit, you notice the people more the more you play ;)

There are glitches in the game yet there are being resolved as we speak!

There is a amazing pvp, sorry i was unable to participate yet so im going to leave it with you get to s :)

Did i mention its full loot?

The developers are nice (i have heard of rude developers/moderators but its like that in every game)
I love this game in my heart and i hope it doesnt die soon.

This game is not for people
:who hate full loot
: is a sore loser
: who doesnt like pvp everywhere
: dont like complete sandbox games (not many games like this out there)
: who dont mind a bad attitude or two throughout there gameplay.

reviewText: Since the beginning of Video Games there has not been a game equal to this open world PvP ready Medieval self motivated sand box of a game. The more you know the more you can do & this race to know & do all the aspects of this game is ever growing. Having played since 2009, the ever changing world has gone from a simple sanbox game to a complex knowledge based game that demands hard work and virtual labors  to achieve skills as well as the first game i have ever seen where reading books for knowledge lores was not only possible but had a real time aspect that allows for offline study as well. The  banking system is town based and the only real safe place to store any loot as the game is complete loot drop upon death for every player making the PvP not only interesting but a reason for bandits to hunt other players However the guild based system makes regions of land in the game player owned and can be ruled with an iron fist or a laxed bandit mentality depending on the players. No place is truely safe in the game but with strength of allies and engineering the player built fortresses can be a safe haven away from common bandits but is no means completely safe as other guilds and players can siege at any point they are able to afford the manpower and resources to  attack the structures & this is becomming easier with time to achieve for even the single players however the group aspect of this game makes most solo adventures suicide or a battle of fierce tactics & combat guile, this does not stop the veterains with all their knowledge lores from roaming and killing every player that moves in the wild & some times even in the towns where the bravest of the murderers still wonder in & kill people and ride out even with a hord of guards on their tale they still manage to evade capture & death with swift & fierce malice to others. beware the others as they are the the greatest threat & strength in this game & practice on the PVE & earn your skills to take rank in the guilds of your choosing, But remember that we are all Mortal" Online. Live well
date: Work hard & Die with style. Enjoy!"

reviewText:
Good game. Plent to do. I do, however, have a few minor complaints. Firstly, it is poorly optimized. Secondly, each additional character slot is $9. I cannot afford this. Third, once you log in as a f2p acc, that account is locked in for the day. You cannot switch accounts so you can use other characters. Additional character slots cannot be purchased through steam and require your credit card info. And finally, subscriptions are 15 EU/month. Being subscribed doesn't give you any additional character slots.

Finally, for some good things. The community. I hear alot of complaining about it. It's really not too bad. The game is difficult. This is good. It's rare in this modern age. Will continue playing.

Needs 1 free additional character slot. 5/10
